review.des:
I came here with my girlfriend and a friend.  We did not make reservations... so it was a 2 hour wait, BUT it was totally worth it.

The place itself is a very lively place, yet intimate for either a couple or a small group of friends.  The middle of the place is a small kitchen were a lot of the pasta is made adante, which is awesome.  

We each ordered a different dish so that we can each try a bit of a bunch of stuff and man... everything was just sooo good.  The pasta had a beautiful texture, very well seasoned, and buttery.  Though the plates look a bit small, they are not - they are very very filling.  

We also ordered some artichokes to much on while we waited for the food and they were equally as delicious!  I know they are just artichokes... but the way they were seasoned and grilled/baked really brings out the best in those artichokes.  

I am very very much looking to come here again in the near future... this time with a reservation :)

Ah, such mixed feelings to write this review. I really want to give Monteverde five stars. But I can't do that after discovering at the end of the meal that my dining companion had BEARD HAIR in his food that we were sharing family style. Beard hair in food is usually a deal breaker for me (aka = zero stars). Who am I kidding? "Usually"? I've never had beard hair served in my food. Pretty atrocious.

Ok, so I'll start at the beginning. We came here to celebrate my brother's birthday over. He lives in the neighborhood and loves to dine here. All the siblings were gathered from near and far.

Ambiance: Very cute. Rustic and chic elements. Large TVs near the bar was a little strange as this isn't a sports bar.

Food: Five of us shared the tuscan kale salad, lillian's stuffed cabbage, gnoccheti con pesto, ragu alla napoletana. I thought everything was creative and delicious (especially the stuffed cabbage). But, I didn't love the ragu. Yes, the portion was HUMONGOUS and we couldn't finish it. The soppresata meatballs and cacciatore sausage were aromatic and flavorful, but the tomato braised pork shank was dry, cumbersome, and weighing down the potential of the dish.

Service: Generally really awesome. Our server was really kind and enthusiastic. He even brought out this beautiful funfetti ice cream cake with a candle, on the house, for my brother. One con about the service (the people circulating the table and clearing dishes) was that they were WAY too quick to grab the plates and clear the table. I like to savor things and leave my favorite last few bites for last. I lost many of my favorite bites because they would just yank my plates away without asking. I thought that was a bit rude.

Ok. So now the dreaded beard hair incident. My brother is a really cool, calm dude. He grew up in a house dominated by women, and an easy going nature helped him survive. As we were finishing some of the dishes nearing the end of the meal, he asks for a fresh plate while casually mentioning he found beard hair. WHAT?! So disgusting. And no, they did not belong to anyone at the table - the colors didn't match. I was surprised that the person taking his plate of beard hairs (yes, there was more than one) away didn't send the manager by. I felt pretty sick since we were all sharing the same food. Ultimately, we all shoved this incident under the rug, as my brother wanted to let it go and enjoy the moment and festive occasion.

I don't want to let this incident ruin such a fond memory of family. I'll keep the feelings of my experience of celebration and family separate from the dining experience. But, I don't think you'll find any of us dining at Monteverde again.

I really loved this restaurant and I totally get all the hype. We came here with a group of 7 and I'm thrilled because tasting everything was a treat. The waiter recommended we get various pastas to share (family style) but since a bunch of people had  various dietary restrictions, we ordered appetizers to share and each person picked their own pasta. Turns out, we ended trying everything anyways!

With respect to appetizers we enjoyed the sunchoke and artichoke crostini as well as the stuffed olives. Both were great!

With respect to pastas, we ordered the bolognese (2), wok fried arrabbiata (2), cacio whey pepe, gnocchetti con pesto, and strangozze al pomodoro. My absolute favorite was the bolognese - it was stupendous. My husbands favorite was the cacio. Either way, I'd eat it all again happily!

For dessert, we had the butterscotch budino (was SO good that I forgot to take a picture) and the forgotten cookie.

Honorable mention goes to the drinks. I ordered the Rumble in the Bronte and I loved it.

Decent spot for a special outing for Italian food. Ambiance and service might have justified the prices. Was the food mind blowingly good? Some of the first bites were, yes, but I think it's easy to get bored of Italian food after the first few bites.

We got an appetizer with crispy polenta that was actually our favorite dish.

I got the cheesy pasta cacio whey pepe ($15), first few bites were seriously surprisingly good because it was more flavorful than I would have thought. But after that it got kind of like a regular heavy Alfredo pasta.

The arrabiata pasta ($18) was good but we thought it would be spicier and flavorful. The noodles would be the best part.

The cocktail ($14) was worth it, tasty but still alcoholic.

Dish after dish came out, each distinct from the previous. Forget notions of spaghetti, lasagna or risotto. Chef Sarah Grueneberg takes you on a tantalizing flavor journey that expands preconceptions of Italian fare.

As an example of unexpected Italian fare, my favorite dish was MELONE E HAM: Pugliese burrata, rosemary lemon tigelle, Casella's 14 month prosciutto, basil for $24. It was served with flat bread that resembled English Muffins but were moist and rubbery in texture (I think our server called it jelly bread, but I'm not sure). We were instructed to slice it open and layer it with the marmalade, mozzarella and prosciutto. It was heavenly. I would have been sated with that dish alone.

Something that happens when lots of food is ordered and my hunger is satisfied early is that I become critical. My ravenous cavern is no longer consuming indiscriminately; instead I eat for pleasure and curiosity. That has happened *EVERY TIME* at Monteverde.

The food is still delicious, but maybe it's too salty. Or maybe I like it but don't love it. Monteverde dishes are served family-style so multiple dishes get compared side-by-side and I inevitably prefer some over others.

I believe that Chef Grueneberg is a gifted visionary and leader and it is evident in the popularity of her restaurant. It is challenging to get last minute reservations, it's crowded and noisy (but not impossible to have a civil conversation). I like Monteverde and I think it's worth trying.

I really liked Monteverde.  Of course, you probably know the plates/portions are small, but everything was extremely tasty.  My favorite was the simple yet complex cacio e pepe.  You can never go wrong with fresh, homemade pasta, and Monteverde did not disappoint.

Hmm, can't remember why I had this place bookmarked and I saw a lot of five star reviews for this place, but unfortunately it was a miss for me. The positives are that the staff was welcoming when we walked in and answered our questions about the parking, plus they seated us right away without a reservation. We did come early though on a weekday.

So they give you complimentary bread sticks when you sit down, didn't like them at first, but they grew on me while waiting for the food, haha. The waiter recommended sharing dishes because according to him, the food comes out at different times because everything is made to order or something like that. I think that they should just be honest and say the dishes can be on the smaller side. Also he kept saying everything was spectacular.

Started off with the octopus appetizer and it was disappointing. Super small, I think it only had two pieces of octopus and the other pieces were leek and I forget what else, unremarkable. Had the skate schnitzel salad which was a good portion and had the perfect crispy breading (worth getting). Also tried the pappardelle with the lamb and it was decent, but not spectacular. Ordered an expensive dish, can't remember the name, but it was basically tortellini with shaved truffles on top. It came with a lot of truffles, but couldn't really taste it and it was just ok.

We ordered a lot of food for two people, so I feel like we had a good sampling of their menu. The service was good though in that they refilled waters, folded your napkin when you went to the bathroom, etc., so I had a hard time deciding on how many stars, but the food couldn't justify more unfortunately. Maybe it's just not my kind of place, it was ok to try once, but I don't think I would come back or recommend.

Boy, this spot is tough to get a reservation for on a weekend. We eventually had to settle for Saturday lunch which wasn't ideal but I cheered up after seeing two words on the menu "brunch cocktails."

Appreciated the high ceilings upon walking in and liked the refined, but not overly elegant vibe of restaurant. You get thin elongated bread sticks as a bread basket when first seated.

My husband got the bloody mary and me, the "not" bellini. His bloody mary was perfection, the fried goat cheese stuffed olives that came as a garnish on it, divine. The bellini was much sweeter than I anticipated and our server was kind enough to sub it out for the wonderful bloody mary.

Every item we ordered was cooked to perfection and flavorful. The flavors were so delicate and precise - I had a real appreciation of their craft. Our server had recommended her favorite, gnocchetti con pesto, and it was our favorite. We also had the not to be missed, and only served at lunch, egg yolk raviolo. Pesce alla griglia rounded out our meal with some fish.

For dessert, you can't go wrong with the panna cotta with fresh fruit.

review.des:
A little overrated in my opinion. My husband and I came here for our anniversary expecting to experience top notch service and amazing food from recommendations from others but it was a pretty mediocre experience.

We got there about 15 min early before lunch time hours were over and before our dinner reservation. It was around 345p on a Friday so there was obviously not a hue rush of people trying to get in. Also they only had 4pm resos available. The entire restaurant had multiple seats open but we still had to wait awkwardly on the side with others for our seat and until "dinner hours" were open. There was still people sitting at their tables from the lunch hour so I'm not really sure why we couldn't just sit at our table since we already had reservations and 90% of the restaurant had open seats. They could be offering us water or to look over the menu.

The appetizer breadsticks were really good and our waiter was really friendly. We ordered the Arancini ( it's ok.), ragu alla napolenta ( good but salty), and the grilled artichoke crostini which all seemed to be the popular dishes. While everything was good they weren't amazing and like a lot of reviews said, very salty. Prices weren't terrible and ragu napolenta was definitely huge!

Not sure I'd frequent this place but glad we gave it a try.

review.des:
Had a reservation for 4 on Saturday Lunch and we were seat right away. Service and decor was excellent. Love how they have fresh pasta hanging in one area of the restaurant!

Bloody Mary was good! Could be spicier and I usually strongly dislike olives but these fried ones were delish and took out that pungent smell from them.

Favorite dish was hands down the Egg Yolk Ravioli! Great truffle flavor, cream sauce was perfect - next time I will order one for myself bc portion is small.

Also ordered the Omas Green Salad which was fresh and had great bites of avocado and the octopus which you can go wrong.

Last we got the Ragu which is a monster. The meat is so tender, the pasta soaks in the ragu nicely and the sausage is very juicy. A lot of elements going on and it's a hearty dish so come hungry if you want.

Overall, loved it and will be back!

I love checking out former Top Chef contestant's restaurants. When I watched Sarah Grueneberg compete, I knew her food would likely blow me away & it most certainly did. Her pastas may look simple but, the flavors they deliver are divine.

We were fortunate enough to be seated right outside the kitchen for a late lunch on Saturday and loved watching the staff at work and Sarah supervising everything. We ordered the 'nduja arancini rice balls and roasted sea scallops as starters, we each ordered a pasta dish - our server gave us each an extra small plate so we could share- and zeppole for dessert. It was the perfect amount of food for 4 people and we all got to taste everything. The pesto, the egg ravioli, the cheese and pepper pasta and the tomato basil pasta were all visually beautiful and exceptionally executed. It's where this restaurant shines!

The kitchen is certainly fun to watch and depending on where you're seated you might also have a view of the pastas being rolled out up above the bar. It's a great experience and our server, Jamie, also provided excellent service. Definitely 5 star worthy!

review.des:
The bf and I came in right at 5 pm with no reservations on a Friday and had no issues with snagging a table.  

While the place might seem extremely fancy online and from reading reviews, it felt more like a nice-casual place.  Meaning, the restaurant didn't give off that pretentious vibe but yet the quality of the food was nothing but perfection.  

The food exceeded my expectations.  We ordered the burrata appetizer along with the arancini and the ragu dish that everyone is raving about.  Everything was spectacular, especially the ragu.  It's so much food for two people and I'm glad we didn't order more pasta dishes.  The meatballs, sausage and pork shank were just so tender.  This restaurant is definitely added to my places to bring friends and family from out of town.  This restaurant lived up to its hype for me!

This is quickly becoming perhaps my favorite restaurant in Chicago. Second visit, we got the pomodoro and pesto again, with artichoke sunchoke crostinos and the burrata/ham plate as starters. I don't know that I'd need to get the burrata/ham again -- it was fantastic, but you can get similar dishes elsewhere. I definitely want to try more pastas and veggie dishes.

For dessert, we got the birthday cake and chocolate meringue cookies, both of which were great, but I wouldn't be against trying other things next time.

Overall, an outstanding spot that I will obviously be coming back to again and again.

An absolutely fantastic dinner experience! Service was spot on, and the ambience is great, even though some of the tables are quite close together. We had the arancini, squash blossom, sunchoke crostini (highly recommend) to start. The Roman eggplant parmesan was probably the best eggplant parm I've had. The skin is left on the eggplant so it is crispy, and the eggplant slices are thick and meaty. The arrabiatta pasta with ground shrimp was unique, evoking flavors of Southeast Asia. The anchovy paparadelle tasted amazing, with tons of shaved truffles on top. The Texas redfish was so moist and perfectly cooked.
The couple next to us ordered the ragu dish ("for the table", $55). It looked huge - I'd recommend getting this if you have at least four people in your party. Or if you're planning on skipping appies and desserts.

Everything we ordered was delicious. Monteverde does a great job making the food approachable and delicious at a moderate price point. Here is everything we ordered, in order of my personal preference:
1. Pumpkin ravioli (seasonal item) - this was fantastic. The ravioli was very creamy and I love the flavor of sage / butter, so I found the sauce delicious! The ravioli also came sprinkled with pumpkin seeds and something crunchy that may have been apple. This pasta was just cozy, delicious, and perfect for fall.
2. Lamb skewers - this was a small plate and a bit overpriced (1 medium skewer for $9), but the taste was great. The meat was tender and the glaze was great (almost had a bit of a sweet taste to it).
3. Apple cake with rosemary ice cream, sea salt brittle, and walnuts - there was so much going on here, and it was all great. Lots of different flavors, textures, and temperatures. The sea salt brittle was the most unique and my favorite part of the dessert.
4. Bolognese (daily special) - this was pretty traditional bolognese. I enjoy bolognese, so I liked it. It's not as unique as some of the other items on the menu, so if you're looking to try new / different items, maybe skip this. The quality of the pasta was definitely really good, and I liked that the pasta was a bit more al Dente than the others.
5. Cacio whey Pepe - this was really creamy and good, but the Parmesan flavor was a bit too overpowering for me. It was delicious, but relative to the other pastas it was lower on my preference.
6. Warm chocolate ganache tart -again, this was good but the chocolate ganache after a few bites was too rich. The texture of the ganache is creamy and flowy, so it's nice. If you're a chocolate fan, definitely order this!
7. Hamachi Crudo - good but nothing super special. The citrus flavor was nice and overall I enjoyed the appetizer, but next time I may try something more unique on the menu.
Overall, this may be my new favorite restaurant in Chicago. It was delicious, and I definitely recommend you try it!

My wife Jun and I recently went on a short trip to meet my parents in Chicago (my mother had a business trip in the city, and my father was tagging along). While Jun and I ended up helping out my mother a lot for her business trip on a fairly hectic schedule, we still had a very meaningful time my parents whom we don't get to see that often as they live in Korea. Before our reunion, my mother asked that I arrange a dinner for our family and four of her business trip companions. Knowing that my father is an aficionado of Italian food, I looked up Monteverde, a leading Italian restaurant in the Windy City for its fresh take on Italian cuisine and superb pasta offerings. I was required to commit to a family style dinner that serves two snacks, two appetizers, two pastas, one main dish and two desserts, at $70 per person plus 22% mandatory "administrative fee" (i.e. gratuities). Not a friendly price tag, but I was more interested in making sure that my parents enjoy a good meal so decided to trust the accolade around the restaurant since its opening three years ago.  

I thought by family style, the portion would still be more or less manageable for eight people, but during the meal it almost felt like the kitchen thought they were preparing a meal for 12 or even 16 people! Not surprisingly, toward the end of the meal the entire dining party started to struggle with eating the gigantic piles of food. There were four females in the dining party (including my mother and Jun) so maybe the kitchen overestimated how much capacity we had in our stomachs? In any event, the snacks ("stuzzichini") and appetizers ("piattini") dishes Jun and I had ordered in advance of our meal were all very delicious, starting with the artichoke and sunchoke crostino where the addition of housemade ricotta and truffle made each bite wonderfully complex, as well as fried stuffed olives with a powerful mix of goat cheese and sausage inside. The stuffed cabbage had porcini mushroom Bolognese and crispy polenta inside for a spectacular effect on the overall flavor, and while if a restaurant in New York City serves skate schnitzel with wok-fried onion and peperoncino (hot chili peppers) this good, I think I will visit that place more often. The temperature and texture of the skate was spot-on, and the spicy kick from the peperoncino gave even more robustness to the dish. The pasta menus at Monteverde are divided into to groups, "tipica" (i.e. traditional style) and "atipica" ("i.e. novel, unconventional style). Jun and I had ordered one dish each, and the one from atipica group turned out to be more successful. The pasta dish from the tipica group, campanelle with blistered cherry tomato, basil and za'atar, was surprisingly off in the flavor, which was a little too overpowering. Expecting a simple, soulful tomato-based pasta, Jun winced at how aggressive the flavor was and didn't touch the dish much. On the other hand, the wok-fried arrabbiata from the atipica group was quite wonderful, with black and white tagliolini (think spaghetti-like thin noodles) and ground Texas Gulf shrimp working beautifully with garlic hot pepper oil to give a flavor that was powerful, interesting and addictively good. As I mentioned above, by the time the pastas were done, everyone was very much stuffed and were startled to see two giant plates of Ragu alla Napoletana consisting of fusilli pasta, sausage, soppressata meatball and tomato braised pork shank. Jun and I felt terrible that both plates were barely touched, especially because all the different components in the dishes were delicious, especially the pork shank that was more or less perfectly braised. Only if our hotel had a microwave so that we could take the leftovers for a breakfast or lunch the next day... In any event, we still had desserts left, and this time the two dishes we had ordered came at a more reasonable portion. Jun and I enjoyed both warm chocolate ganache tart accompanied by hazelnut praline, banana caramel and vanilla ice cream (which had an attractively rustic quality) and butterscotch budino with buttered pecan and whipped mascarpone (with a bruleed top that you can crack with a spoon), and mustered whatever space in our stomachs we had left to savor these delightful desserts.

Monteverde is still a very popular restaurant in Chicago, and during our meal we saw that late diners were showing up at as late as 10 p.m. so I highly suggest booking for a table in advance. There is full bar with heavily Italian wine list; my father ordered a bottle of Chianti Classico from the Tuscany region that everyone enjoyed to complement the meal. The flavor at Monteverde could be slightly more moderated for my and Jun's taste, but there were still a lot of exciting dishes that I think makes this restaurant still one of the hottest tables in Chicago.

review.des:
Last night was my second visit. The friend I dined with is vegetarian so we opted out of any meat or fish dishes. We each had a glass of red wine and started with an artichoke & sunchoke crostino which was light, fresh and delicious. I could have had another but ...

Next up was the gnocchetti con pesto. I took my first fork full and thought it was salty and maybe it was the fault of one of the cheeses. Then my friend took her first bite and said ... this is wrong (she's been there 6 times before and said she's had this dish every time and it was definitely too salty) - so our waiter got us a new order of the same item which was perfect!

Since we were ordering 1 thing at a time, next was the green mountain salad. I poo-pooed having a salad b/c you can get salad anywhere, right? But this was full of yummy veggies with a delicious dressing and my favorite type of lettuce. VERY good.  And I was glad she talked me into it.

Our last dish was greens - sauteed, I think. Maybe some ricotta mixed in?

Finally (because we were celebrating my birthday) - our waiter brought over a piece of cake - white with vanilla ice cream, burnt marshmallow and sprinkles on top. Very yummy and a lovely finish.

My sister and I came yesterday evening for dinner and had a great meal with seating next to the kitchen. The plates here are meant to be shared which was perfect for us since there was so much we wanted to try.  To start we ordered the burrata and ham which came with a generous portion of the  cheese and a bunch of freshly made bread that I can only describe as the product of what would be if a bao and an English muffin had a baby. There was also prosciutto and the melon with this dish and we opted to add prosciutto butter for an additional price. This was a totally worthwhile choice and I would come back to eat this as a meal by itself, it was that good.

For drinks we had a white wine and also a cocktail named Sardinian Bandit! It's sweet and then finishes dry  (or perhaps it was the other way around) with an egg white foam. Super refreshing and right up my alley.

On to the pastas- all are made in house except the cacio whey pepe in which the bucatini is shipped from Italy, as I'm told. The agnolotti is made fresh to order. We opted to try the pappardelle with shaved truffle and the special of the day pasta which had a tomato base and scallops. Both pastas were individually robust and unique in their combination of  flavors. The shaved truffle made for a truly decadent dish although I didn't think the corn in this dish did much as it would be fine on its own or perhaps be enhanced with another veggie or meat.

Dessert - lots of options and each sounded delectable! We choose to try the blueberry lemon Sundae and were happy with our choice.

The last part of my review would be nothing but praises for Rose, our server! She was very attentive and knowledgeable. She always checked up on us yet never overbearing. Our water was never empty and overall we enjoyed not only the meal but the service was spectacular. Before our meal even ended we already started to plan on a return visit.

Check out the menu and pics! I am salivating looking at the burrata already lol!

review.des:
I came here for my birthday dinner recently. I'd heard good things about it but had never been. Primarily because I don't generally eat carbs or dairy so I tend to steer clear of Italian. But on your birthday you have to indulge - right?!? And let me tell you it was WELL worth it!! We started with the burrata. Who doesn't love burrata?!? And it was divine. Served with prosciutto, melon and these little carby pillows. I don't know how it gets better. We also tried the octopus skewers and the hamachi collar. Amazing. But the real stars are the pasta. We ordered the pesto and the cacio whey pepe. Both were perfection but the cacio whey pepe - I'm still dreaming about it. I have literally never had better pasta in all my life. Ever.
Cocktails were fantastic and service was attentive and friendly. This place makes the carbs worth it.

I have to say I was able to attend for a special event but I would jump at the chance to go back anytime the opportunity arises! The restaurant is so beautiful and you can watch behind the bar as the make home made pastas! I had the honor of meeting Chef Sarah. She is so down to earth and knows her stuff! She is a force to be reckoned with. The FOOD! The prosciutto (PBT) butter toast was out of this world and I don't even like radishes. From the schnitzel fried skate, pugliese burrata and melon, sheep's milk angolotti, pappardelle, grilled red fish, and that bone in rib eye! Oh my, my, my! The wine parings were so on point. We couldn't get enough. And I have to say the dessert was one of the BEST, absolute best things I have ever put in my mouth! The butterscotch Budino. HOLY COW. I think I have dreamt of it at least twice since having it. I could have 12! Add Monteverde to your must go list immediately!

This place was excellent. Every dish was truly perfect.
PBT- gorgeous... maybe the most delicious idea for butter ever created. Truly beautiful plate and taste.
Fiore di zucca- soooo tasty. Just order t. Spicy sweet creamy and crunchy.
Sheeps milk agnolotti- maybe the best pasta we had- delicious.
Cacio whey Pepe- intensely creamy. I love the addition of ricotta whey. One of the best cacio e pepe I've ever had.
Egg ravioli- really good but slightly underwhelming.
Zeppole- absolutely loved these, tart raspberries,  creamy center, perfectly sugared and fried
Scrambled egg fonduta- really cheesy and tasty
Amatriciana poached eggs- loved this. Toast was great. Similar to shakshuka but with Italian flavors. Loved the guanciale.
It's a beautiful restaurant. I loved the mirror that shows the women making pastas by hand. Overall lovely experience.

review.des:
Cacio whey pepe: I am always critical about the texture of noodles. Chef Grueneburg nailed the texture of noodles for sure, no wonder she is the "queen of pasta". The cream was very, very rich. Your taste buds are swimming in the pool of rich and flavorful sauce and then gets slapped with the fresh cracked peppers that leave them wanting another a bite.

Strozzapretti with baby octopus: This dish was completely different from the cacio whey pepe. It had a whole different profile of flavors and texture. The pasta was a little bit tougher to the bite, but it needed to be to handle all the other flavors. The octopus were braised to tender perfection. It was a little bit on the saltier side, but it wasn't terrible.

Every bite was better than the last! Everything was so delicious that I couldn't pick a favorite (although anything truffle makes me very happy). We had reservations for lunch so we didn't have a wait. The waiter was great with his recommendations. The man who filled our waters and folded our napkins was fantastic. Very sweet, offered his suggestions and fixed the slight wobble of the table without being asked.  The three people in our party left satisfied and full after sharing 5 items, including a desert, but we didn't feel too stuffed or sick. I almost can't wait to go back!

What a great experience this was. I can honestly say this was one of the greatest meals I've ever had. Portions are generous, presentations are craveably rustic, and taste is just fantastic.

Food:
I came during lunch, which I specifically mention because some of these items are not on the dinner menu. I had the following...

Artichoke Sunchoke Crostino:
These are large crostinis which you order by the piece for $5. The bread is probably just under an inch think, and is piled high with soft and creamy ricotta and fontina. The cheese is topped with artichoke, sunchoke, and truffle which covers the entire surface. They are rich, have just the right amount of truffle, and are indulgent but not overly so for a snack / starter.

'Nduja Arancini:
To quote my wife, "I want to live in this arancini." We both agreed that this arancini made us feel like we had never eaten arancini before. Hands down the best I've ever had. The outside layer is very crispy / crunchy, but not too thick. The inside is a warm, spicy, soft, melt in your mouth mixture of the spicy sausage, manchego, and risotto. They are topped with an insanely good aioli with a ton of spice/herb flavor and also a perfect tomato sauce. After we finished the aranci, we were scooping up what was left of these sauces with our forks and eating it straight. One order comes with 4 arancini for $8.

Egg Yolk Raviolo:
Cutting into this and seeing the yolk flow out was spiritual. It blended so well with the truffle and corn sauce surrounding the raviolo. I have no idea how they accomplish this masterpiece ... I am guessing there is some kind of ricotta moat so the yolk doesn't harden, and I'm really in to the concept of ricotta moats.  If you are hesitant about the anchovy, don't be. The flavor is not overpowering in the least, and the pieces are so small you wouldn't be able to visually tell there was anchovy in it. The anchovy really has a faint crab-like flavor that goes so well with the sweet corn. For the regular sized pastas, this is the priciest at $24, but it's absolutely worth it. (All of the others are $15-$20).

Ragu alla Napoletana:
Our server was excited to deliver this to our table and explain what was going on since we has not had it before. This is an enormous dish. It consists of a mound of fusilli pasta, 3 full sausages, 4 large meatballs, and a mountain of a pork shank, all covered in a rich tomato sauce. The fresh pasta had a great texture that stood up to all the meat on the plate. It was dense, and had just a bit of a chew to it. The sausages were thick and juicy; you could see the juice when you cut into it. They also had a pleasant little amount of spice to it. The pork shank was huge! As soon as I put my fork to it, basically all of the meat began to melt off the bone. It was braised to tender perfection in that tomato sauce. The soft pork with the dense pasta made for a really awesome bite. Finally, the meatballs. These were the best item on the plate. They are soppressata meatballs, so they have a complex spicy taste. Like the sausage, they were incredibly juicy. I tried to take small bites so I could savor them as long as possible. We ended up having a good amount of this dish left to take home with us. It's $55, but it's honestly a really good deal for the amount and quality of food you get. I just ate these leftovers for lunch and everything reheated really well too. (I forgot to mention there was green stuff on this plate too, because I had meat goggles. There was a small salad of warm and salty escarole. I presume this was there to cut into the richness of all the meat, but I have no shame / restraint and just plowed through until I had to roll out of my seat).

Other meal aspects:

Atmosphere:
The restaurant is modern / industrial but also cozy, and made me feel at ease. Waiters wear aprons over their nice casual outfits. It's not stuffy, and you won't feel judged if you don't order super expensive bottles of wine. On the regular drink menu glasses of wine go from $10 to $15 in most cases, and bottles from about $35 to $70. They do have a more extensive wine list if you're into that, where the median bottle price is probably in the $60s. I visited for a late weekend lunch with my wife, and we opted for cocktails which were $14, unique, and delicious. I had the Chef's Gin & Tonic, which had muddled cherry tomato and basil. It was super fresh and light, and I want another one right now. My wife had the "This Is Not A Bellini" which is made with sparkling sake. I think it was named "not a bellini" because it wasn't messing around. It was strong but fresh and light.

Service:
Very good; I definitely have nothing to complain about. We were regularly checked in on by our server or his helper, and our water glasses were never empty.

Yes.

This place is delicious. I wish I came in a group so I could pick off other people's food and try more dishes. Guess I just have to come back on my own!
Fiore Di zucca - so flavorful in all the good ways. I want this again... and again.
Pork Loin Skewer - Also tasty! But I'd probably get something else to try next time.
Spaghetti Alla Chittara - the truffle was so prominent yet not overly prominent. Just so freaking good.
Arrabbiata - Perfect amount of kick and substance. Tasty!
Chocolate Tart - I don't normally get dessert, but this was pretty tasty, too!

So many other pasta dishes I want to try now. it was also cool being able to see them make pasta at the bar area. Ambiance was classy yet casual. Waitstaff was fantastic.

pics.caption: Spaghetti Alla chittara - truffle goodness. Get this.

review.des:
Dropped by for brunch and loved it! The restaurant is beautifully decorated and the ambience is spot on. The second you walk through the door you feel comfortable and can just sit back, relax and eat. You can see employees making the fresh pasta right behind the bar. The restaurant opens exactly @ 11:30AM on the weekends so don't come too early otherwise you will be waiting outside.

The food was very tasty! My favorites were definitely the Zeppole, the pork shank and the tuna bruschetta. The Zeppole or the doughnuts were so amazing with the raspberries and vanilla crema. It wasn't too tart. The pork shank was so soft and broke apart the second you picked it up. The dish was definitely way bigger than all their dishes. I didn't get to try the truffles. But definitely will be back and give that a try.

The service great! Everyone was super friendly and attentive. The hosts took us to our seats right away and we sat towards the back. The server was really friendly and checked up on us a lot. We always had a full glass of water and a clean table. I am definitely going to be back. There are so many things to try still.

Came with a party of four and we ordered too much even for big eaters. For a group of four I would recommend maybe two small plates, a pasta and the big Ragu Alla Napoletana. They also have a rib eye, I might give that a try next time. Definitely make reservations.

We walked by this restaurant 5 days after returning from 16 days in Italy....so pasta was not on our mind.  It smelled so good as we lingered in front of the door, we had to go in.  AMAZING!!! I would even go as far as to say better than pasta dishes we had in Italy.  

Atmosphere: even waiting an hour, standing at the bar, it was a warm authentic atmosphere with great wine and cocktials.  We ended up getting seats and ate at the bar.  The bartenders are on point with both their spirits and wine knowledge.  At the bar, you also get to watch them make the pasta!!

Appetizers: artichoke & sunchoke crostino- the truffle on top was delicious.  You will not be disappointed.  The order is for one little piece, order your own.  You will thank me for that suggestion.

Octopus spiedino- I am a lover of octopus, so yes, I'm alittle picky.  This was pretty small.  Flavorful, yes- but on a skewer the pieces are quite small.  I would try something else next time.

Pasta: wok fried arrabbiata.  This is amazing.  Great spice.  If you like spice- order this.  The shrimp in the pasta is the perfect protien choice for the spice.  Robust, satisfying, perfect spice to this dish.

Lamb Ragu- this was under their daily specials.  One of my favorite pasta dishes ever.  It has this sweetness in the sauce with a nice light noodle.  The lamb was tenderful, seasoned perfectly.  This was a fish where if you put your fork down to breath, you might not get anymore.

I cannot wait to come.

After hearing so many good things about this place, I was pretty excited to give this place a try. I came here on a walk-in around 6pm and luckily we were able to get seated in one of the few unreserved tables. It was our first time so we asked the waitress for recommendations.

Liver Bacon Burrata (5/5): this is one of their specials of the day, and I'm glad we got it. The flavor of the toppings blended together very well with the sauce. I'd highly recommend trying it if you see it on the menu.

Wok Fried Arrabbiata (3/5): This pasta was too salty and it reminded me of an overly greasy chow mein from an Asian takeout restaurant. They did throw in a good amount of shrimp on there though.

Cacio Whey Pepe (3/5); This pasta was pretty bland, not in the sense that there isn't enough sauce. The flavor was pretty flat and neither of us enjoyed it a whole lot. The texture of the pasta was on-point though.

Overall, I would probably still recommend giving this place a try because of the amount of rave this place has received. Maybe I went on a bad day, who knows. The waitress and hostess were all very courteous.

review.des:
I finally was able to visit Monteverde...for a work dinner at 5:30pm one night!  

This was actually my second visit.  My first was at the bar (also a hard seat to get).

This spot is gorgeous and I love watching the pasta being made.  It's cozy and comfortable and definitely a perfect spot for almost any occasion (giant group dinner...perhaps not as it's hard to get a seat and it gets a bit loud).  Service is friendly (on my first visit, they helped me get a seat at the bar by letting me know who was getting seated next!) and they don't rush you even though the spot is packed.  This is nice because I really dislike being rushed out.  

Everything I had was great.  The meat/cheese plate with the homemade bread - YUM!  It was so simple but so flavorful.  I also tried the ragu on the second visit and while I was initially skeptical of sharing giant entrees with my work team, it worked out really well.  We were able to try a lot and the larger plates truly can be easily shared.  Some of the meat dishes are very rich, so a little goes a long way.  Perfect for a cool fall day!

Pricing isn't inexpensive, but I thought that considering the freshness and quality ingredients along with generous portion sizes, that the price was ok.

Worth a visit if you can get a reservation, and I highly recommend trying to do so.  Otherwise, plan to come very early and try to snag a seat before they open.

Food - 5
Service - 5
Bathrooms - 5
Value - 4
Atmosphere - 5

Boom... And just like that, one of my new top three restaurants in Chicago.  My first visit and I'm a huge fan. Not sure if the food is always this exceptional or they are having a lucky night so I'll have to come back again soon and check. :-D.  Not often I'm surprised and delight like I am now. Congrats to Seth and the entire Monteverde team for exceeding my expectations!

pics.caption: Crispy Squash blossoms stuffed with ricotta basil, tomato vin with honey. Very good.
Stuffed with sheep mik ricotta and topped with pork sugo and marinated Melrose pepper. Excellent!
PBT. Prosciutto Butter, radish, seeded rye toast, and lemon marmallata. Fabulous!

review.des:
The service, the desserts, and the creative cocktails sneak this one up to a 5 for me. We had 2 outstanding pastas and some good creative combos:
Octopus spiedino with leek and sweet potato, grilled and set in pimento sauce. (Good, cooked well)
Burrata, prosciutto, fig, and an awesome rosemary flat bread. (Chef recommends cutting it open and making a sandwich, and we did! This was 5/5.)
Gnocchetti con pesto was perfection. 5/5
Ricotta agnolotti with chanterelle mushroom, plum, thyme sauce and topped with Burgundy truffle was my fave! 5/5
Wok-fried, black and white arrabbiata with shrimp in chili oil with a side of a melt-in-your-mouth meatball (Brian's favorite thing we had, but was a little sticky for my taste and I'd rather have had full shrimp instead of little shrimp bits).
And we *might* have gotten 3 desserts by accident... The chocolate ganache tart was eye-closingly delicious. The butterscotch budino was lovely. We also got a slice of birthday ice cream cake (even though it's neither of our birthdays -- thus the 3rd dessert by happy accident). It was beautiful but not nearly as decadent and tasty as the other two. (Though it was nice of them to still give it to us even after we clarified that it wasn't our birthday!)
An incredible meal and experience. We went at 5:15, ready to sneak in at the bar when available and managed to get one of their last walk-up tables. Glad we did!

Monteverde is a cute little pasta restaurant. Street parking only and it can get crowded without a reservation.

For a party of 2 we split an appetizer and two entrees. They started us off with crunchy pretzel like bread sticks. We ordered the stuffed cabbage, lamb ravioli, and the smaller portion of the Texas redfish (pesce alla griglia).  My favorite surprisingly was the cabbage dish, savory, cheesy, very unique. I didn't like the ravioli as much as it was a bit gamier than I would have liked. I think probably we should have ordered a differebt pasta dish. The fish was quite good, perfectly cooked where the meat was very moist.

I liked the drink I had - stop and smell the roses. It was beautifully garnished.

pics.caption: Stuffed cabbage with fried duck egg

review.des:
Enjoyed our brunch/lunch at Monteverde. A wide range of options on the menu, and between two of us, we tried to do a bit of everything.

The things we loved:

- The truffle and artichoke bite off the snack menu. They even cut this in half for us to share - but you should have one per person because it's so good
- The pesto dish was also fabulous - light, refreshing, with a lovely delicate taste

The thing that was most different:

- Probably the cacio y pepe...theirs is much creamier due to the whey I believe. I prefer the focus of mine to be on the pepper, but in this case, the focus of the pasta was the creaminess

The things we would pass on next time:

-The egg yolk ravioli...the sweetness overshadowed the truffles for me, which is the whole reason we got the dish
-Fiore di Zucca - if you're a ricotta connoisseur then definitely get this! I will stick with the artichoke and truffle next time, because that was my preference

I would recommend giving Monteverde a try. Make sure you don't skip over the pesto - it's fabulous!

Sorry, Monteverde...I wanted to love you but I just haven't figured out why this is one of the highest regarded restaurants in Chicago. I've been twice now, once for drinks/appetizers, and another for restaurant week, and both times I was underwhelmed. Perhaps it's just not my kind of restaurant...or I haven't yet come for a standard sit-down dinner yet...but considering all its accolades I just find it underrated especially compared to all of the amazing dining options in the West Loop.

Service and ambiance were nice. Cocktails and wine selection were solid. And the food was good. But if I'm going to spend money (and calories!) on an upscale pasta dinner, I need it to be a wow and Monteverde just didn't do it for me.

My usual M.O. in picking a restaurant is usually on hype, reputation, reviews, reading its menu and sometimes just a feeling. Most of the time I'm spot on, rare occasions am I disappointed. But, what's even more rare is when I catch such a "Winner" and am so overwhelmed with the experience that's taking place that I get completely awe struck.
This is exactly what happened to me and my party of five today
at Monteverde!
Everything Monteverde brought to you was spectacular; the ambiance, the service, the cuisine choices, the beverages, the price your paying for what your getting and of course the food!

All was remarkable.
Let me show you:

Mozzarella Di Bufala - I've had this dish in 200 places. Never have I used my index finger to lick up the plate!

Scrambled Egg Fonduta w / shaved Blk Truffles - Singlely one of the best brunch egg dishes I've ever had!

Salumi Arancini - rivals NYC's Arancini Bros. and that's all they make!

Egg Yolk Raviolo - We shared this dish and fought over the portions. What else can I say!

Gnocchetti Con Pesto - I closed my eyes while eating this dish and was transported to an outdoor seaside trattoria in Genoa. Wow was it good!

Creste Di Gallo - The texture of this unique pasta was amazing. I can't even describe it's crunchy, yet soft chew-able feature. All I can say the pomodoro type sauce it was bathed in just kicked this plate up 5 notches.

Small Pesca Alla Griglia - Texas redfish, sliced heirloom tomato, shell bean salad, arugula, Sicilian almond / What a combination of ingredients. We voted this our favorite plate of the day!

Roman Eggplant Parmesan  - This casserole was rich, tasty and our finale. It was marvelous!

Panna Cotta - the perfect ending to this perfect meal!

Getting blown away like this is such a treat for me. I never expect it (anymore) but when it does happen, I'm delighted and appreciative for the talent it took to do this.

As I have said in the past, I don't give out 5 stars very often. But Monteverde is special and both times that I have gone have been perfect. Well, almost.

What's most striking is the organization of the house. Servers, runners and cooks go about their work in an almost serine manner. There's no weeds in this place. The dishes come out timely and are paced nicely. Best to go with a group, if you like to sample the city's best hands down handmade pasta and other delights.

The Cacio Whey Pepe is orgasmic, and I don't use that expression lightly. Really creamy, if you know what I mean. Etherial. I'm not sure if I could handle a single portion. Two twirls of this cheesy, creamy noodle in my mouth. Yes, I almost blew my wad.

So, we had some other dishes. I won't elaborate on those dishes, only to say that my fork twirled amongst those of my friends at the table, and we all moaned and groaned... and sipped wine. See, this restaurant, led by its uber talented chef, Sarah Grueneberg, to me is all about execution. Hell, that's what serving food is all about. Doing it the right way. It's not easy, but these Monteverde gals (and guys) get it done. They bring you the dish and you enjoy the textures and depths of flavors.

One last thing (a note to Chef Sarah)... If they took that Cacio Whey Pepe and added some pancetta and a creamy egg yolk, they would arrive at my favorite pasta dish, Carbonara. If Chef would do this for me the next time I visit, assuredly I would cream in my jeans.

The food and service is amazing!  This place is definitely a busy one!  I came here for dinner with my fiancé, and we tried the Arancini, burrata, skate schnitzel, cacio whey Pepe, arrabbiata, and a truffled pasta special of the day.  The skate schnitzel was absolutely amazing, and all of the pastas were incredible, too.  I have to go back to try more of the menu!  We tried the chocolate ganache tart for dessert.  It was super decadent!

I came here a second time for lunch with my friend after telling her how good this restaurant is, and it didn't disappoint!  I had to have the burrata again.  The tigelle that come with are sort of similar to English muffins but are so much better.  We also had the stuffed cabbage hat comes with an amazing mushroom ragu and crispy potenta.  We had to have a few pastas including the cacio whey Pepe again, since it's so amazing, the raviolo, and gnocchetti.  Everything was so good.  They forgot to bring us the artichoke and sunchoke crostini, so Sarah Grueneberg brought it out herself!  The service was once again amazing.  There are few places I would go back to, but this is definitely one of them!

My favorite restaurant. Not just in Chicago. Period.

Monteverde is my gold standard. It's reason why so many restaurants I eat at end up disappointing me. It's the reason I measure my purchases in $35 increments: because that's how much a typical dinner at Monteverde will run for me.

Monteverde is the reason why I've already planned out my wedding, graduation celebration, and funeral in advance: because my girlfriend tells me that I can't plan out just the caterer without planning out everything else.

All hyperbole aside (not really), Monteverde represents the pinnacle of Italian food for me. Not only does it represent some of the most amazing Italian fare I've ever had, their culture is one of the best I've ever seen in a restaurant.

First, let's talk about the atmosphere. One thing I adore about Monteverde is how accessible it is. Although the restaurant is booked two months in advance, the large bar area means that if your willing to wait for a few minutes, you will get a seat. Furthermore, the prices are fantastic. The only Italian restaurant that I've been to that even compares to Monteverde is Babbo's. Luckily Monteverde comes at a similar quality, half the price, and without any of the problematic signals associated with Babbo's. For $35, you get food better than any One Michelin Star I've ever been to.

Side Note: The fact that Monteverde does not have a Michelin star is a crime that makes the Game 6 of the Kings-Lakers Series look like a legitimate basketball game. I'm not bitter.

At this point I've had just about everything on the menu, but a running theme is the incredible amount of effort and creativity that goes into each dish. What really distinguishes Monteverde and separates it from the pack is that they are still innovating a cuisine that has existed for hundreds of years. Whether it's their vegetarian bolognese that makes any meat bolognese blush, or their Wok-Fried Arrabiata that makes me cry, Monteverde is willing to take risks and innovate in a way many restaurants aren't. Chef Sarah and Chef Riley have truly created something amazing.

I love the fresh made pasta here!
Everything was delicious! We got Black Truffle Egg Yolk Raviolo and tagliatelle pasta with a glass of champagne to start our morning as tourists in Chicago!

I've been here twice, once for a double date dinner and once for a girl's day saturday brunch. Amazing both times. The ragu is so flavorful and the shank falls apart on the plate and melts in your mouth. The meatballs in the ragu are incredible, best restaurant meatball I've ever had. We got so lucky and chef Sarah came out to check on us, it made the experience so special. Even the salad was amazing, the dressing was so spot on. The other standout was the giant ravioli, pictured below. The ambiance inside makes you feel like you might be in an italian pasta shop instead of chicago. The home made pasta is so fabulous I wish I could take some home. I try to make a reservation here every time I am in Chicago. Simply the best.

My Yelp batting average for 2018 is sorely lacking in plate appearances. Let's get back to the dish.

Like many a fellow Yelper, there's a hole in my heart and a hurt in my belly on the death of one Tony Bourdain. My wife likes to joke that Tony and I on a first name basis, based on how many times I casually name drop him during our eating adventures. Correspondingly, my Yelp reviews are replete with Bourdain mentions. He changed the way we think about food, about company, about life about how simultaneously large and small the world is, about how we are unique and similar, different and the same. He will be missed.

There exist many Bourdainism moments that stick with me - some famous, others fleeting, transient, exceptionally important only to a handful. And to me. One of those is a No Res episode in Rome, where Bourdain eats a dish of cacio e pepe. Hearing him gush exquisitely over this exceptionally simple plate of noodles immediately stirred me into absolutely having to try and make this meal post haste. As much as I can visualize Bourdain enjoying one of life's simple pleasures, I can visualize myself in the kitchen, mise en place, boiling pasta, grating cheese, melting butter, crushing pepper.

So it has been told that a fundamental reason we love to eat is the way dining cajoles our memories. Such it was with Monteverde's cacio e pepe, a wonderful dish in its own right, but an especially sentimental one to me. It's undoubtedly Sarah Grueneberg's best dish, among a bevy of strong contenders, I had that night; Yelp reviewers tend to agree. Though I'd argue, you can't go wrong with any of the pastas. The arribbiatta, another personal favorite, was top-notch, and the raviolo special equally fantastic. I'd also urge not to pass up the stuzzichini starters or Sara Lamb's desserts.

That cacio e pepe, though. It's ingrained in my brain, a searing memory urging me to revisit again soon.

Enjoyed my first meal finally at Monteverde. I've been dying to try this place. We shared the ragu which was very good but I enjoyed both the Wok-Fired Arrabbiata and the Skate Schnitzel even better. I'm glad I tried it but I would not order the Ragu again unless I was in a big group. The meatballs in the Ragu were the best. The Ragu and the Arrabbiata were both tomato based but the Arrabbiata was full of garlicky, herby flavors. Plus, it has shrimp in it! The Skate, though, omg! It was fried and delicious. I can't even describe the flavors, there were so many. I licked this plate clean. Our friends also enjoyed their scallops and other pastas.

Oh and I had the Cherry Bomba and some red wine. Both were excellent.

I wish the portions were larger for the price but I thoroughly enjoyed it!

Lets start with the bad...
1.  Our server was not good.  Unattentive.  Non directional.  We just didnt mesh.  1/5
2.  Reservations are less than stellar...only way to reserve is online.  No way to call for reservations.  Completely booked for good times for at least 2.5months ahead of time!  Ouch...the price you pay for a great restaurant.  2/5
3.  We only ate a little bit of gnocchi, arrabiatta and ragu.  We asked to pack it up to take home and at the end of the meal, they handed us a large bag.  The next afternoon when we were excited to dig into our leftovers, they only put the ragu in the bag!!!  No gnocchi and no arrabiatta.  Very annoying.  We purposefully ordered everything so we could try a bunch but then have leftovers for the next day.  0/5

Lets talk about the middle of the road...
1.  I didnt love the decor.  I felt like I was in a food hall or cafeteria from Harry Potter or Game of Thrones.  3.5/5

Lets finish with the good...5/5
1.  The freaking food was some of the best I have ever had.  Amazing dishes from start to finish.
Fried olives were absolutely amazing.  Crispy outside with a little piazzazz of mustard and the right amount of salt.  We loved these.
Swiss Chard and polenta...the chard was in a white cream sauce, perfectly sauteed mixed with chunks of polenta that was crispy on the outside, but buttery and creamy inside.  Perfect.
Eggplant was such a complex dish.  You could taste the roast on the veggies.  Loved the hearty red sauce...slathered in melted cheese.  YUM.
Gnocchi were perfect little shell like pastas with a herbaceous basil cooked just over al dente with the right amount of pecorino...heaven.
Arrabiatta was great, however out of everything, it was our least favorite...not because it was bad, but because everything else was so amazing.  The pasta was great.  Little bits of fried up shrimps with a little bit of a spicy red sauce.
Lastly...the ragu.  I am so glad my husband talked me into this dish despite the server telling us its made for 2-4 people.  It was HUGE.  However, it was also the most amazing dish of the night.  The meatballs were the PERFECT texture...not too dense and not too crumbly.  Sausage was amazing and that pork shank...  You can tell this dish has some love put into it.  
2.  All of the other staff except for our server!  Every other person we encountered was personable, nice, our speed..from food runners, to the front of the house staff, to other servers.  5/5
3.  Chef was dining with some friends right behind us and we rudely interrupted her to tell her how much we loved the food.  And in true top chef fan nature, I asked for a photo with her.  Alas, she was literally the nicest person ever.  Made my experience!  5/5

I am totally late to this party, but Monteverde is definitely a place to check out in Chicago.  The calories/carbs are worth it...I just wish I could enjoy our leftovers today... :(

Monteverde has been on my radar for a while now.

I would recommend making a reservation, however if you come early before a dining rush hour, it would be possible to get seated at the full-service bar as my boyfriend and I did.

The waiter told us that the dishes run a bit small and it is encouraged to order ~4 dishes, presumably 2 appetizers, and 2 pastas, or two small dishes and 1 large dish which can feed 2.

Roasted sea scallops: This came with 2 very large, and extremely succulent scallops. I do not think the lentils did much to enhance or complement the scallops, but both the scallops and lentils on their own could have been separate delicious dishes.

Egg yolk raviolo: From the bar, we could see the cooks making the pastas fresh for each new order. I did not realize that the raviolo came as one large ravoli filled with ricotta and a soft egg. The description seemed a bit misleading as I expected a lot of smaller-sized ravioli and a very creamy sauce. I wasn't a big fan of the dish. The flavor seemed monotonous from the and there was a sweetness to the dish that I didn't expect. The pasta itself had a great texture. I wish I had ordered a different pasta dish with more actual pasta.

Cheekstone farms 24oz prime bone-in rib-eye: This was a near perfect dish. Everything was delicious from the seasoning on the rib-eye to the umami brussel sprouts to tart, chewy dried tomatoes. The only issue was that we ordered it to be medium-rare and there were several parts that were more on the rare side.

Overall, the rib-eye totally impressed me. One of the best meat dishes I've had but I was truly disappointed that I didn't enjoy the pasta here as much as I would have wanted to. I'm teetering between a 3.5 and 4 on this review. It's an impressive restaurant but I can't say it ranks among my top Italian restaurants in Chicago.

Garnering accolades from day one for Pasta visibly made on-site and a rustic-chic approach to Modern Italian fare it was on Saturday afternoon that Brunch was ordered at Monteverde, Chef Sarah Grueneberg's 2017 Beard Award for Best Chef Great Lakes hanging proudly on the wall and the outdoor patio quick to fill while the interior was perhaps at 1/3 capacity.

Opened in 2015 and a Best New Restaurant awardee the following year, time under the guidance of Tony Mantuano allowing Grueneberg access to great Ingredients but apparently never convincing her that pretense and a good view were necessary, guests entering Monteverde will immediately notice a homey feel despite see-and-be-seen layout, the waiters and waitresses all professional yet genial whether describing plates or suggesting Wine while back-servers do world-class work keeping glasses filled and making emptied dishes vanish.

Slightly varying the daytime menu from that at night, Brunch plates lining the left column with Snacks, Small Plates, Pastas and dishes "Per la Tavola" to the right it was after a discussion of serving sizes that four items were requested, a one-by-one procession begun by two styles of Grissini from which savory bested sweet while a $6 follow-up of three Zeppoles immediately made Dessert a necessity thanks to unrivaled lightness beneath Cardamom Sugar and Raspberry Jam plus plenty of warm Vanilla Cream for dipping.

Originally planning to go all-in on Pasta, those thoughts reconsidered when the waiter described "generous" portions, it was instead "#Montemadame Toast" that next found itself compared to a similar Croque-riff from The Loyalist just one day prior, both Radish and Black Pepper helping to refresh a classic but Fontina Cheese simply not as enthralling as well-made Mornay Sauce.

Next presented with Gnocchetti and instructions *not* to mix the Ingredients so flavors could stand apart it was admittedly interesting to see the variance in textures ranging from creamy to leafy before disobeying and creating something far better with a few stirs, the famous "Cacio Whey Pepe" to follow intensely saline on first bite but subsequently mellowing as heat developed in the mid-bite before permeating the sinuses.

Turning things over to Pastry Chef Sara Lamb to finish, time at The Pump Room and now Monteverde Restaurant & Pastificio making her a name to watch, it was ignoring warnings from one Staff member that two Desserts were requested, the $12 Butterscotch Ice Cream Puff manageable by one thanks to delicate Choux, Meringue and complexities created by Booze and Fruit plus Buttered Pecans that all contributed to something greater than the sum of its parts while the Warm Chocolate Ganache Tart was admittedly a dish best shared thanks to its thick Dark Chocolate that even Bananas, Caramel and Ice Cream could not make seem lighter.

Monteverde is an exceptional restaurant.
Exceptional food.
Exceptional service.
It's even a great value compared to other restaurants of its caliber.

I have not tasted anything at Monteverde that I would not recommend, but if I had to pick a few highlights, they would include Roasted Sea Scallops  and Stuffed Cabbage -- two of the "small plates" that were complex and delectable (and FWIW could easily serve as a main course).

Among pastas, the Arrabiata is rich and intense with minced shrimp, anchovies, and chili oil, and the stuffed pastas are literally made (i.e. stuffed) to order, but the best of the bunch may be the deceptively simple Strangozze Al Pomodoro.

The entire wait staff is cheery, helpful, and efficient. If you are lucky enough to get Rose as your server, you'll find a waiter who is very knowledgeable and adept at explaining the menu, and eager to make your evening a delight.

Desserts are as insanely good as the rest of the menu, so save room.

Came for a celebratory dinner and was amazed! There were four of us, so we ordered a lot and shared. Started with the octopus, artichoke crostino and rice balls. They were all so good, but the artichoke crostino was by far the best! The truffle mix with the cheese and delicate artichoke was so good! We shared the eggplant parm, gnocchitino, wok shrimp pasta, cacio whey pepe. The pastas were so unique and had such well balanced flavors. The gnocchitino was my favorite again, with the pesto being light but rich in flavor all at the same time! We also had an order of really delicious meatballs that just melted in your mouth. We finished with a celebratory cake from the chef, and we had to try the budino too. The cake was like an adult funfetti cake on a new level. The toffee budino was unreal- I had no idea what we were ordering but I will order again every time we're back. It was so delicious! The chef stopped by our table and was gracious enough to take a picture with us. A great atmosphere and eating experience!

Update: Next visit with photos- also amazing! Please get the lemon blueberry dessert. Our server convinced us and it was one of my favorite desserts in Chicago. I was nervous because my husband isn't a huge lemon guy but OMG it was bright and salty and sweet and just absolutely delicious. Also, the gnoccheti continues to be a favorite.

Let's put it out there--lots of people love Monteverde...and lots of people are perplexed by why so many other people love Monteverde.  I was nervous coming into this meal because my "work wife" thinks this is the best restaurant in Chicago, while two other couples I know had classic hit-or-miss experiences.

I'm happy to say that for whatever reason, we had a five-star experience.

Positives:
--the food, all of it that we tried:  the ahi tuna crudo, the pappardelle, the arrabbiata, and the salumi sauce arancini.  I mean, all of the flavors, the prep, the presentation, the serving sizes...all good
--a couple of these dishes are a roll of the dice, none more so than the wok-fried arrabbiata, so as a menu goes, it's fun to try some things that freshen up the idea of "stale" Italian, and you can tell the restaurant prides itself in this area
--the space, although while I'm calling this a positive, if I had been seated right next to a loud group of six, this could have gone the other way.  Just know that the way Monteverde lays out its varied seating options, you could get unlucky with the people rightnexttoyou
--it's semi-easy to get a table here during traditional dinner times on Tuesdays and Wednesdays so try to take advantage!
--quality cocktails, but...

Negatives:  none that we experienced, but again, I have food friends who I trust who had only average experiences here.  This really will come down to ordering the right things, but even the arrabbiata was a dish that one friend of mine disagreed with, even though she was excited to try fried pasta.  Also, we skipped dessert (this is rare for me) because we were meeting friends after this dinner elsewhere; I've not heard exceptional things about the sweets here!

Everyone makes mistakes. How well you handle those mistakes is what sets a restaurant apart. We spent my 40th birthday seeing Hamilton (simply incredible!) and went to Monteverde afterwards. We started with Oma's Green Mountain Salad and went for the 24 oz prime rib. Regretfully, the prime rib was taking quite awhile to arrive. Before we could speak with our server, the manager, Amy, stopped by to apologize. She acknowledged the wait and provided a glass of wine free of charge for our inconvenience. The steak was amazing! We finished dinner with the butterscotch goodness and tart. Our server also gave us two cookies on the house, since we were struggling between those 3 desserts. Thank you to the staff of Monteverde and their manager for making my 40th birthday dinner wonderful!!!

Overall: Romantic, delicious, and unique, Monteverde deserves all the hype it receives.

The good: The atmosphere is refreshingly non-Italian, even if the bulk of the menu is. There's a uniqueness to it that's almost indescribable in that it's almost like you're in an outdoor patio (which they also have). The service is friendly and attentive, but the star of the show is obviously the food. The ham e burrata is, as always, good, but the beets were what made the dish stand out. They were flavorful, unexpected, and were a pleasant addition to the traditional pairing. The pesto gnocchi was also out of this world, with potent traditional flavors. The cheeses and sauces were rich and, by themselves, unbelievable (which is how the chef recommends you eat them).

The not-so-good: The skate schnitzel was surprisingly disappointing and nothing about it wowed me in any way. The gravy was bland, the fish itself forgettable, and the dish is overall just an odd combination. Also, the arrabiata, while good, was over-hyped and over-spiced. It was too intense overall. Also, be prepared to book far in advance, because even when we did several months ahead, we still only had an 8:30 option.

Atmosphere:10/10
Service: 9/10
Food: 8/10

Thank you, Monteverde, for not letting me down. Thank you less for the fact that my pants don't quite fit as well today. [Wish I could give it 4.5 stars]

The place: Had reservations at 8pm on a Wednesday night (that were made a month in advance mind you) - and it was PACKED when we arrived. It's not a small place, but every. seat. was. taken. There was slightly more than a dull hum permeating the air, but I was pleased to find that I could still hear my friend very well across the table - not something I take for granted in the Chicago dining scene. In a few instances it felt a little too crowded - I may have accidentally bumped ass first into 2 or 3 servers, but they took it in stride. And hey, it's not that often that my ass gets bumped at all, so all in all, not so bad. Service was great. Re-filled our waters, checked on us appropriately, made a helpful recommendation.

The taste: Yum. Yum. Carbolicious yum. We shared the hamachi crudo - cold, crisp, spicy, delicious. The octopus with leeks. We devoured this. Small bites, but tasty ones. The cacio whey pepe.

Cacio whey pepe deserves a line all its own. While not traditionally creamy, this dish had some creamy elements and reminded us of a very sophisticated adult mac and cheese. Absolutely divine in its simplicity, restraint, flavor profiles. I could eat that every day (if I wasn't worried about my ass bumping into more people).

We shared the daily special - the egg yolk raviolo - perfectly seasoned, rich, delicious. I love the runny yolk. We shared the gnochetti with pesto and pecorino - we thought it was good, but a little on the salty side. We couldn't quite finish it, because we wanted to leave room for dessert. We made a solid dent in the chocolate ganache tart. It was good, but we probably should have stopped.

She got a glass or two of wine. I tried the saba soda - which was interesting - it's made from grape must and was likened to balsamic vinegar.

My face: Carb-filled smile. Wow. This was a great meal. Check off my bookmark list (yay, feeling accomplished!) Bill for 2 was $128. Worth it. Will be dreaming of the cacio whey pepe (and the fact that Chef Sarah Gruenberg made an appearance) for a while.
