review.des:
Monteverde is perfect in every way. The staff truly cares about their business and values how they present themselves, and the food they put forth. I fell in love with the melone e ham. The prosciutto, burrata, and bread encompasses the essence of a warm homemade meal.
In addition, the staff was incredible! Our server was knowledgable about the Italian wines they offer and provided impeccable suggestions.

Probably my most favorite place I chicago and one of my most favorite pasta places overall. Great scene and the pasta is great- get the arrabiata - something that is unique but excellently done.

The place is packed but bar seating comes and goes quickly.

This was a fantastic meal.  Our server was very friendly and was able to help us decide when there were so many options.  There were three of us (all women) and we ordered about 5 dishes. They were all delicious and it was the perfect amount. We even had a little room for dessert which was also fantastic.  Our server was really great at explaining how the menu works and recommending these dishes to us. I highly recommend coming here; I know I look forward to coming back to try the next round of dishes they cook up for the next season/menu.

Whatever you do, please treat your tastebuds to this fantastic restaurant when you're in the neighborhood. There is no choosing between this restaurant and another- eat here!! We had a fantastic time- they bring each table toasted thin, long breadsticks in a mason jar to start.  We had an impeccable strawberry tuna tartare appetizer and lastly split the Ragú- THIS IS A MUST. They make their own homemade noodles (can actually watch them being made through a ceiling mirror) and pasta sauce. The pork was literally falling off the bone. And the spicy meatballs were to die for. This is pricey but it's certainly large in portion and taste.

We had a great time with delicious food and excellent service at Monteverde for VDay dinner. We ordered two small plates and one big dish to share.

Octopus Spiedino - this octopus skewer was my favorite dish of the night. The texture was flawless. Leek in between the octopus and the sauce made the octopus more palatable.

Smoked Fish Rillettes - loved crispy polenta and salad on this pretty plate! Crispy polenta has a very thin and crispy shell with soft boiled cornmeal in the middle. It reminded me of fried rice cake ("糍饭糕") - a traditional local breakfast option in Shanghai. The salad on the side with dried cherry tomatoes has a little bit of sweetness and sourness that went very well with the fried polenta. The dish would be perfect had the smoked fish be less savory.

Ragu Alla Napoletana - the decent amount of food on this plate is enough for 4 people to share. The flavorful sausage and super tender pork shank were my favorite! Pork fell off the bones easily and it melted in the mouth. Meatball was delicious, but also very filling. I'd like the fusilli rustico to be boiled a little longer and wild oregano be less greasy.

Butterscotch Budino - brûléed top with chocolate crumbs, rich chocolate pecan toffee, and whipped mascarpone made it a perfect ending for a sweet date on Valentine's Day.

We are definitely going back to try other interesting things on the menu.

I could limn this place. I could recount, in an assiduous manner, how phenomenal the foods were. But at this point, they'll just be words arranged neatly on a page, paragraphs of malarkey. There are places you describe and places you experience; and this place, my friends, is the latter.

However, this is Yelp, so let's detail this roller coaster of an experience, shall we. Their budino is what brought us here, but I'll touch back on that later...let's start from the very beginning.

Bread sticks...awesome! And they're complimentary, LoL. They were very flavorful, I'll just leave it at that. Do try them, though.

We started with the 'njuda arancini (the rice balls). So imagine the best pizza puff you ever had and exponentiate that by a million (flavor-wise) except there's rice and the outer was crisp to perfection--that is what you are dealing with here and on top of all that, there's this glorious aioli they serve it with.

Then we moved on to the artichoke and sunchoke crostino. Let us pause for a sec and give this masterpiece the respect it deserves. If there is one thing that you need to try while you are here...IT IS THIS! I'm not going to be even describe it because it will fail on all fronts...the English language does not have enough adjectives for you to fully grasp the craftsmanship that went into this dish. You just need to look your waiter/waitress in the eyes and ask for the crostino and I'm just going to end this paragraph with: YOU'RE WELCOME!

Now we moved on to the gnocchetti con pesto. This is even harder to describe than the crostino. I mean, that gnocchetti...swoon. If a person can fall in love with food, I most definitely am madly and deeply in love with this pasta. Then, they sprinkled in the pesto and that ricotta, shaved in the Sardinian pecorino, and it doesn't stop there...they topped it with basil and pine nuts. It's the true embodiments of the highest quality of ingredients done in the most simplistic of ways to deliver an out of this world experience. It was clean, it was delicious, and it was every flavor working together for the common good of blowing your taste buds into oblivion!

My friend got the pork cheek tortellini in brodo, which in short could be deduced to the Italian ramen. The broth was so flavorful. The tortellini and the pork cheek cheek inside it, wow. Again, clean, flavorful, everything working together to enhance and not overpower. It was a great bowl of delight.

For dessert, we got the house spun ice cream and sorbet of the following flavors: passion fruit, blood orange-cranberry, and coconut milk. And not to sound like a broken record, yes, it was simple, clean, and everything a sorbet/ice cream should be. The texture was amazing, it was creamy, and you taste the flavor of the fruit without being too "icy". It was light and palate cleansing. My favorite was the passion fruit and my friend liked the blood orange-cranberry. But, in all honestly, it was all great, you really can't go wrong. It was served with three coconut-chocolate forgotten cookies, which is actually befitting because they were forgotten because of the amazing-ness of the sorbet. Not to say they weren't good, we were just too busy eating the sorbets.

Now, this part, I'm somewhat conflicted about: their butterscotch budino. I couldn't grasp this dessert one bit. In my opinion, it was way too salty, almost like I was eating a cup of ocean water...like my internal concentration was bordering on saline water proportion. I couldn't taste the butterscotch because the salt was too overpowering...the whipped mascarpone helped a little to lessen the saltiness, but it could not be salvaged. Even the brûléed topped did nothing to sweeten the dish. On paper this dessert seemed amazing, but a big let down in reality. But then again, it was the very first budino I ever ate, so not sure how salty it's supposed to be. Maybe I'm bias towards the sweeter spectrum of desserts. Maybe for some budino master, this is how it's supposed to be. The texture of the pudding was great. It's disheartening that the experience ended in such a weak note.

However, with that all said, this place still gets my highest recommendation because I do believe that one bad thing should not jeopardized the rating of a place. I still believe I came away with a great experience and their food was solid. I wasn't feeling one item, they shouldn't get ding for that, maybe someone else might taste that and it'd be the best thing they ever ate.

In short, go try this place, most everything in their menu is awesome. I'd come back to try every single thing in their menu for sure.

The food: 4/5. I tried their restaurant week menu, which included squash crostini, salad, redfish, pasta with meat ragu and citrus sunday for dessert. Everything was very satisfying and very heavy, as expected from pasta dishes. However, I didn't love their wine pairings. The reds were just ok, and I wasn't at all a fan of the type of amaro they offered after dessert. Grappa or Fernet would've been a better option.

The service: 4/5. The service was fast, but not that friendly.

Overall: 4/5. A good Italian option in Chicago.

The service, food and ambiance were all great at Monteverde. I was there with a large group where we tried a variety of items including: skate schnitzel, artichoke and sunchoke crostino, gnocchetti con pesto, cacio whey pepe, ragu alla napoletana, nduja arancini and the oma's green mountain salad. I also had a dirty martini -- including delicious blue cheese olives (a major plus in my book).

The items at Monteverde are recommended as shareable, family style items. So, just be prepared for that. In a large group, I'm not a big fan of sharing... especially when it's a mixed group of folks that I don't know very well. So, that is really what I didn't love. When with my husband or close friends, I may consider otherwise. But, if your weird about sharing food, this may not be your spot.

I'd definitely try Monteverde again, I'll just be sure to be prepared to share!

I really wanted to like this place but it didn't live up to the expectations. I had been wanting to go to Monteverde for a while and was excited to try it after finally getting reservations. It's difficult to get reservations so make sure to plan several weeks in advance! The ambiance is nice and dim. Our waiter was friendly but the food here just didn't do it for me.

We started off with the PBT ($4 a piece) which was pretty good. We ordered a few cocktails ($13 each) which were also good. For the main dishes we decided to share the tortelloni di zucca ($15) and their famous ragu alla napoletana ($49). The tortellini was pumpkin filled and delicious. Our waiter had warned us that the ragu was a very large dish and good for groups of 4-5. He was right - it was huge. It comes with pasta, sausage, meatballs, and pork. I had high expectations for this dish because of all the Yelp reviews but l wasn't impressed. I thought the flavor was quite plain and not memorable at all. Although it's worth $49 because it is a very large dish, I would not order it again.

For dessert we tried the butterscotch budino which was ok - almost too sweet, and that's saying something since I'm such a sweet tooth. We paired it one of the desserts wines (tiny glass for $9) recommended by our waiter but I didn't think they went well together.

Overall, even though so many people had raved about it, I wasn't impressed with Monteverde.

Came to Monteverde on Tuesday and our reservations was at 5:30pm. We were seated right away when we got there. Service was on point.

We started with the Artichoke and sunchoke crostino. This was pretty good. Then we ordered the pork liver mousse. I was not a fan of that. It had a some horse radish like taste to it and I don't like horse radish.

For our entree we decided to share the Ragu Alla Napoletana. The pasta is massive. It can definitely feed 3-4 people. There was only two of us and we couldn't finish it. The pasta was ok. The meatballs were too mushy for my taste. The sausage and pork meat was good. The sauce tasted like spaghetti sauce.

It was a decent place but I wouldn't come back again.

After looking at where I dine, I realized that I don't do enough Italian for fine dining or restaurants. Kinda odd considering that I like pasta quite a bit.

Anyway, second day in a row scratching off a place on my list that had been on there for a long time. Much like Fat Rice yesterday, Monteverde lived up to its hype. I was a little worried because Italian and/or pasta is one of those things that can be hard to separate yourself and stand out from other Italian restaurants. They achieved that easily.

The spread we went with was the crostino and the schnitzel to start. Aganolotti and Arrabbiata for pasta and then finished it off with butterscotch for dessert. The starters were recommended by the server. Honestly, I was skeptical at first because schnitzel can be hit or miss and crostino sounds boring. They were anything but. The crostino looked and sounded simple but it was flavorful and a fantastic, unintentional pair to the schnitzel. And the schnitzel... jeez, that came out much larger than what we were expecting. Again the flavors here we fantastic, the tomatoes and onion had a nice sweetness to go with that savory and crispy pork (I think it was pork? Haha). Definitely recommend it.

Both pastas were great. Let's get that out the way. For me, I liked the aganolotti a tad more and she preferred the arrabbiata. It's splitting hairs really, both were great and can't wait to return to try other pasta dishes. Finished the night with the butterscotch and some tea and left a very satisfied customer!

Ambiance was nice and romantic although a bit louder than expected. Small bar in the middle with a tv to watch a game if you chose. Wine selection is great.

Garlic sticks were fantastic and extra crispy which I loved with the presentation of a mason jar. The artichoke crostino was our favorite dish which was quite unique. I had their version of an old fashion which was way too sweet! Don't order it... Taste like blood orange liquer.

The wok fired shrimp with garlic oil dish sounded unique but was deceiving as there was barely any shrimp and the mix of black and white pasta brought a bitter taste.

The egg yolk ravioli was interesting with what was the largest ravioli piece I have ever seen but has way too much truffle oil on it and took away from the creamy cheese... Personally go to Momotaro and try their what yolk pasta instead!!!

The gnoccetini with pesto was solid... Great flavor and extremely fresh hence the extra star.

Desert we had the chocolate tart which just has too many things going on with banana ice cream marshmallow and candied nuts it felt like cold stone and tart.

I did ask for a side order of the sausage but it was never brought out which was a dissapppbtment.

For a place that we waited a month to get in I was very dissatisfied overall!

Was alright.

Service: This was where they shined. From beginning to end, our waitress Rose was the star of the night. Attentive, helpful, not overbearing, and all around super nice! Also, water glasses were frequently replenished.

arrancini- the aioli beneath them was better than the actual rice ball. Pretty average

Burrata e ham: delicious! Def cut the little Italian English muffin in half and make a Sammie. So yummy and the proscuitto butter is next level

Tortellini verdi: was really not feeling this. The miso sauce made it feel like tortellini teriyaki. Ew

Gnocchetti: pesto flavor was good, but the pasta itself was more reminiscent of shells & cheese than gnocchi

Baked apple croute: YUM
Chocolate ganache tart: alright

review.des:
I honestly don't know how a restaurant can get any better. Food, ambiance, service, price point, wine selection... all fabulous. We were lucky to nab some reservations about 3 days in advance for a late lunch at 1:45. Only time slot open the entire day so I grabbed it!  The place was fairly packed when we got there but we were seated right away at the table in front of the kitchen. We got to see amazing things come out which got our mouths watering even more. The Ragu was extremely popular and I can see why by just looking at that mound of deliciousness. We opted for the sea scallops (perfectly cooked) and nduja arancini for starters and both were incredible. All 4 of us shared our entrees and every single one was a winner. I opted for the campanelle al pomodoro with blistered cherry tomatoes. Amazing. And it was only $15. Boom. My wife got the Cacio Whey Pepe which looked kind of plain sitting in the dish but the taste was off the charts!! It was one of our favorites and I will order that for myself next time. The gnocchetti con pesto might have been the best pesto I've ever had and that's saying something! And the egg yolk ravioli?? Spectacular!

I have found a new place to add to my favorite list and another place to take friends when I want to impress them with some amazing Chicago cuisine. Total winner all around.
All the food was flavorful and they offer generous portions. Service was quick  and friendly.

Gotta give this a rare 5 stars: the food won me over.

As a group of 4 we were able to order 5 dishes and 2 desserts, and it is no overstatement to say that most of the dishes completely blew us away with how utterly delicious they were. We left super full and very satisfied.

The pretty, instagrammable PBT (prosciutto butter toast) was a star, and tasted just as good as it looked, with tons of unami and freshness packed onto that slice of rye. The Italian style donuts were such a value for money, at $7 for 5, and accompanied with an orange blossom honey creme, it made us very happy right off the bat.

For mains we chose the pesto gnocchi and the ragu, which we were told is suitable as an entree for 3-4 people (this is accurate).

For anyone familiar with the liguian trofie al pesto (one of my favourite dishes across all of Italy), the pesto gnocchi reminds you of that- the pillowy gnocchi melt in your mouth, along with the bright pesto and creamy cheese.

The ragu was a hearty meal- there was fusilli pasta, meatballs, sausages, and a pork shank where the meat literally slid off the bone cleanly at the gentlest prodding (see video).

Sight disappointments were the desserts- we tried the butterscotch toffee pecan one and the chocolate ganache tart with almond praline. The former was extremely rich, sweet, buttery, salty- nice as a first bite, but I was sorely missing some relief from that full-on sweet-saltiness. The chocolate ganache tart was alright, good but not sensational. We should have chosen a refreshing sorbet after all that ragu!

Our friends called desserts for (a certain equally popular Italian outfit) but mains for Monteverde.

Amazing Italian tapas joint. We got two dishes between two people and were good. We got the Tuscan kale salad and the eggplant parm. Both were so delicious. Everything on the menu looked amazing though. I'd try to save room for dessert too because they have an awesome looking menu! The house made breadsticks were too salty tho.

Wow. Monteverde completely blew me away. I went here with my family while home for the holidays. We always go out for a big Italian meal, but we decided to change up the location this year and I think we've found our new family tradition! Monteverde has a very creative menu that's set up to be consumed as shared plates - which is great 'cause if you're like me you're going to want to try everything.

The PBT was like nothing I've ever tasted before. I mean, take a salty meat and butter and add a bunch of delicious fresh veg? You have to try this app if you go here (even if you're just there for a sip and a bite at the bar).

The Chicky Chicky Parm Parm meatballs were on special. They were essentially chicken parmesan meatballs that were deep fried and oh, so good.

The Winter Kale Salad was really, really good and carried some unique flavors that left the salad tasting perfectly balanced.

The Seared Scallops (served with lentils and pork belly) were delicious. The lentils soaked up all of the flavors in the bowl.

We intended to share pasta, but I got greedy and kept my pumpkin tortellini all to myself because it was melt in my mouth amazing. With apple, a balsamic glaze, and fried sage leaves, I was in heaven.

For dessert we split shared the Butterscotch Budino, Baked Apple Crostada, and *Surprise!* a delightful birthday funfetti ice cream cake. All were yum and went great paired with some espresso.

This all goes without saying that the service was out of this world - our waiter, Sam, gave us great recommendations and was incredibly attentive throughout the night, picking up on the fact that it was my dad's birthday even though no one actually mentioned it in his presence.

We had a great evening celebrating my dad, and I look forward to more celebrations here in the future.

Went here about a month ago and since then I have become convinced that they are producing some of the best Italian food (particularly pasta) in the city right now.  

We sat outside on a Saturday afternoon (heads up dinner reservations are tough but lunch time seems to be much easier if you want to come check this place out).  We had several small bite apps, including a fantastic fried zucchini flower.  The money is in the pasta, and we had a gluten free member in the party who was also able to order pasta and I will say this was bar none the best gluten free she or myself had ever tried.  It both tasted and had the texture of true pasta we wondered if they had been accidentally been real pasta - it was not (Gluten free pasta lovers rejoice - this is the place to eat for you).  Pappardelle with pork sugo and the never to be missed cacio whey pepe (made with ricotta whey - NO WHEY!!!) were absolute winners.  The service was so friendly and welcoming (we brought a young 2 month old with us which was no problem here).  The wine list is quite nice and we had a delicious orange wine that was a BIG hit at the table.  

This place is truly special and I am so glad that in a city with such a wealth of great Italian food that they have found their space here.  Chef Grueneberg deserves her accolades and perhaps even more.  Grazie mille Monteverde!!!

This place was recommended to me by a friend and I am so glad that I took her up for it. The restaurant has intimate seating, which translates to you being able to hear other people's conversations pretty clearly if you can't tune them out. Other than that, this place serves up some deliciousness. Plates that my friend and I shared consisted of:

- Fried squash blossom stuffed with ricotta and honey drizzle = 5/5
- Octopus spiedino = 3/5
- Burrata e ham with prosciutto butter = 5/5
- Wok-fried arrabbiata = 2/5
- Chocolate-dipped forgotten cookie = 5/5

If available, everyone must try the fried squash blossom - a light mixture of sweet and salty and very addictive! The other dish that put my friend and I in pure ecstasy was the burrata e ham. This was essentially a build-it-yourself fancy ham and cheese sandwich with the bun slathered in meat butter. Adding the sugar snap peas (part of the green accoutrements on the plate) gave it nice crunch and sweetness that unexpectedly worked quite well. We could have skipped the wok-fried arrabbiata since it was way too salty (I should have listened to other reviews), and the shrimp was grounded so not even considerable enough to be considered a shrimp pasta dish in my opinion. We barely touched this dish and could have lived without it since the burrata e ham was quite substantial in quantity for the two of us. We did have room for a small dessert and coffee and was glad we both chose the forgotten cookie because it was quite memorable. An airy meringue with a slight saltiness to it - salted caramel perhaps?

All in all, a great place to try out while in Chicago. Get the burrata e ham though!

pics.caption: Forgotten cookie was very good and light

review.des:
Monteverde was a long awaited bucket list item ever since I came to Chicago a year and a half ago. I was able to grab reservations for a Friday night dinner about a month in advance (this is usually the expected wait, but I'm sure it's easier to get a 4 pm weekday reservation).

I was really looking forward to monteverde because it's a classic Italian restaurant in the city, but I think I set my expectations a little too high. When looking at the menu, I was pleasantly surprised at how relatively inexpensive the pasta dishes seemed for a dinner menu. I then realized this is because the portions are about 2/3 of what a regular portion would be. My waiter recommended two small plates and two pasta plates for two people.

We got the roasted sea scallops appetizer - two scallops for $20 which seemed a bit ridiculous, but each scallop tasted like it was $10. Definitely one of the more memorable seafood dishes I've had, but not a regular splurge I'd be willing to pay for. We then got the Cacio whey Pepe and Pork Cheek Tortellini in Brodo. The cacio whey pepe was very unimpressive. The ricotta was too strong and the pasta was too sour and al dente for my preference. The pork cheek tortellini comes in a soup form with a 72 hour pork broth. On one hand, I could taste the 72 hours. On another hand, if you told me that the soup came straight from a can, I would've believed that too.

Overall, I believe monteverde has missed expectations. I've definitely had better pasta in the city and I had to book this dinner a month in advance which contributed to the hype. I also believe that I just chose the wrong dishes. As expensive as it was, the scallops really were great. But my monteverde experience could've been significantly different had I gotten pasta I know I traditionally prefer. Regardless, the ambience was perfect for a Friday night and I would definitely consider revisiting in a year or two.

If you pay attention to the food scene enough, you'll become accustomed to certain names and understand you should probably eat at their establishments. Sarah Grueneberg is a name that's been out there for the last few years for everything from winning some more national awards to coming in 2nd to become an Iron Chef.

While visiting Chicago, I knew I needed a solid meal and something my girlfriend would love. This came to mind as I have some fairly picky friends who reported back really good things about Monteverde.

From the start, the service was excellent. Very hospitable and our waitress was full of good suggestions. The interior is nice and inviting as well and is definitely a place I'd feel comfortable in more than just once.

As far as the food goes, everything we had was at a minimum solid. We felt that the small plates and appetizers were done a little better than the entrees. The level of creativity on some of these was really good - the PB&T with prosciutto butter, radish, lemon, etc. Did I ever think of these combinations? Hell no, but it works really well and looks great. Artichoke & Sunchoke crostini? Great. Smoked fish rillettes? Does not sound amazing but the combination of all the flavors together really works. Some of these things are approaching Michelin star level to me and surprising they didn't even get a bib gourmand - I digress, but still. What the hell?

For the entrees, we had the egg yolk raviolo and cacio whey pepe. The egg yolk raviolo is one big raviolo with a cast of flavors around it that just work like pecans and morel mushrooms. The cacio whey pepe is a more standard dish but done pretty well. My only complaint is that the cacio whey pepe was a touch salty but not too bad. All of the pasta is made in house and cooked perfectly (at least in my opinion).

All in all, I was extremely pleased with my meal and would return here in a heartbeat. I don't know what the Michelin folks are smoking, but this is bib gourmand at the very minimum with some dishes easily approaching 1 star quality. The service was excellent from start to finish too. Much recommended to any lover of good, solid food and even some dishes that you may think "I would have never in my life thought of doing that."

Fantastic meal! The service was beyond excellent- they were attentive, helpful and quick!

We wished we would've tried more pasta dishes, as we went with the scallops, Brussels sprouts, Arancini balls and ragu. The ragu, although large, was just more meat than pasta. I'm also not a huge fan of pork, but it was still tasty. That's really just a preference thing, though. Dessert was great, especially the ice cream. I would definitely try again.

Warning: reservation required far in advance!

This place was truly excellent. The food, while not as creative as some of the other hot & trendy places, was cooked homemade with fresh flavors. Though, add this to the list of places where it's next to impossible to get a reservation.

For apps we got...
-nduja arancini (3.5/5)
-octopus spiedino (5/5) One of the best things we got!
-burrata e ham (4/5) very good! Especially the bread that comes with it.

For pastas we got...
-Cacio whey pepe (4/5)
-gnocchi (5/5) the pesto makes this!
-ragu (5/5)+ also a winner, it was HUGE amount of food that we couldn't even begin to finish. The meatballs were so flavorful!

And even after stuffing our faces we had to get dessert. The budino, the unsung hero of the meal. We didn't need the dessert, but it was well worth it.

Prepare to leave here with a lighter wallet but a FULL belly. Only note of criticism, the pacing of the dishes could have been better.

Came to Monteverde for dinner to celebrate my 3rd anniversary and had an amazing time! The service was spot on, the food was delicious and my dining companion was perfect. I will definitely be dining at Monteverde again, for dinner and brunch.

What we had:
*Artichoke and Sunchoke Crostino - 5 stars, highly recommend.

*Octopus Spiedino - 2.5 stars, wouldn't get again.

*'Nduja Arancini - 4.5 stars, highly recommend.

*Skate Schnitzel - 5 stars, highly recommend. I wish we'd gotten two of these.

*Gnocchetti Con Pesto - 4 stars, recommend.

*Wok-Fried Arrabbiata - - 3 stars, just OK. I'd recommend you get two Skate Schnitzels.

*Ragu Alla Napoletana - 5 stars, highly recommend. This dish is truly meant to be shared as it is huge. The meatballs, sausage, pasta and pork shank were all delicious!

*Baked Apple Crostata - 4 stars, recommend.

*Warm Chocolate Ganache Tart - 4 stars, recommend.

Overall, Monteverde gets 4.5 star for being a bad ass restaurant that I will definitely be going back to!

Monteverde was an amazing place to have lunch with my family. My little sister had initially recommended it but I didn't truly believe her until we started eating. We started off with the artichoke and sunchoke crostini which was a great starter. For $5 per crostini, it is on the expensive side but the taste was really good for a starter. My other family members also enjoyed the Octopus spiedino but I did not try this one as octopus is just not my thing.

The pasta is truly where Monteverde shines. It's exactly the al dente pasta I crave. We ordered 3 different pastas and loved them all! The cacio whey pepe is a smaller dish - I would recommend to share with up to 3 people. It's such a simple dish with simple ingredients but because it was done so perfectly, this was one of my favorites. We also got the Gnocchetti with pesto. It was my first time having gnocchetti (honestly didn't even know this was a thing) but I LOVED the baby little shells! I really liked the added touch of basil and pinenuts but for me personally, there was too much cheese in the dish.

To round out the meal, we ordered the huge Ragu alla napoletana which is a huge bowl of deliciousness filled with fusilli pasta, 3 sausages, 4 Italian meatballs, and one large pork shank in the center. All the components were so good on this dish with my favorite parts being the super tender pork meat on the shank and fusilli pasta. I just cannot rave enough about the pasta here. It is seriously SO SO SO delicious. I even went to Eataly after this meal to purchase pasta as I was so inspired after this meal.

Amazing service from Amanda - she was so pleasant and upbeat! Our waters were refilled so frequently I don't think I ever had more than half a glass empty. I think the meal was truly quite affordable for the amazing pasta dishes and a great place to have a family style type meal. If you're planning on coming, I would definitely try to make reservations at least 6-8 weeks in advance if you can or at the very least call before you arrive to ask about the wait time!

Everything here is so delicious, and the wine list is great too. Our favorite dish was the Ragu, but the pumpkin ravioli and the Cacio whey Pepe were also amazing. The Ragu is huge, and the meatballs and pork shank are so tender and flavorful that the dish is well worth the price.

I walked in  and was lucky enough to grab a seat at the bar area. The bartender was very helpful in food recommendations and helped me through the right amount of food and his own personal recommendations, which was well appreciated. Price is fairly reasonable given the food quality and how popular this place is.

I ended up ordering the truffle toast, pesto gnocchi, ravioli, and chocolate tart.

The fresh pastas were great of the two I had I preferred the ravioli. The pasta had a nice bite to it and had a nice al dente texture to the ravioli.  Can't really go wrong with pesto and the dish had a nice balance with the pine nuts and cheese.

My favorite part of the meal was the truffle toast. If I knew how good this was I would have ordered one less pasta and ordered two more of these. I can eat these all day (disclaimer I really love black truffle).

Chocolate tart was also delicious and I'm glad I ordered it even though I was pretty stuffed from the meal.

Monteverde has won a number of awards including James Beard best chef Great Lakes. had watched the season of Top Chef Texas where the chef was a finalist. I knew the pasta would be great from her time studying in Italy, the dishes she made throughout the season.

I reserved for 15 people (11 adults and three children and one baby) for Sunday lunch. They were very accommodating even for a guest with food restriction. We ordered set menu and they were all fabulous. We had to change last minute with the food since they were all out but it shows how popular these food can be. I would totally go back again for other dishes.

Food and service is spectacular! Joe who was our server was very attentive although it was extremely busy. He provided great recommendations. It's best to share plates and treat it as family style meal. So much to enjoy! Would recommend this place to everyone....even children at the table next to me were enjoying their meals.

Food was great. Service, not so much.

The guy pouring our water was amazing. Our glass never went empty, and he was always there when we needed to find out server.

And that's the problem. Our server never checked in on us. She checked the tables aorund us, but not us. Hopefully if you decide to go you'll have a better experience!

I expected to like this place as I went to one of the tapings of Dishaliscious and had some of her food (including some dried gnocchetti, which are small shells and nothing like gnocci).  I did not expect to be blown away.  Seriously Michelin, this isn't on par with other Italian restaurants in NY and SanFran?  Disagree wholeheartedly...but I digress.  There were four of us for lunch on a Sunday at 2:15.  It was sort of a last minute idea and we were pleasantly surprised we were able to get in before their limited menu kicks in.  We were sat immediately and our server was very friendly.  It is not a very large spot but they have an inviting bar area and the restrooms are nice as well.  The wine list is primarily Italian but they have a few other options as well.  We started with a Champagne, which had about a 1.5x markup but was good.  The Nebbiolo we had for the second bottle was about a 2x markup so nothing unexpected there.  The star of the drinks (according to all four of us) was the Shakernato with Creme de Cacao (the server thought it was dark as opposed to light but he wasn't 100% sure).  Two others tried it with other spirit options but nothing was as good as the Creme de Cacao and this was one of the best after dinner drinks I've ever had.  My husband got the vintage amaro flight and it was good as well.  Overall, portion sizes and pricing was appropriate and service was paced well.
You start with breadsticks and the rosemary ones were super awesome.  You really got a lot of olive oil flavor in there, although the wheat honey ones didn't really do it for any of us.  We like to share dishes anywhere we go, even if the menu isn't designed for that but fortunately the menu here is definitely conducive to sharing.  I was told by a friend to get the ragu at the end because it is large but even better on day two so we knew we had to find four other dishes for us.  The amount was perfect for four if you're looking to share and we did have a little of the ragu leftover at the end.  We started with the arancini and the exterior was so crispy that we all asked if they were double fried and were told they were not but I have no idea how she gets that perfect crunch.  The spice level is perfect as well and they are bursting with flavor.  The cheese concoction on the bottom is so tasty and the dish overall set a high bar.  The burrata came next and as far as preparations go, this is one of the best I've had.  The burrata itself was nothing spectacular but we've had a lot of burrata, including in Italy so that is not a knock on it but the whole dish with the beets and ramps made the dish take on a spring flavor and the prosciutto was actually really solid.  But the star on that plate was the bread.  I don't know what was in there (other than milk and lard cause the server told us that part) but this bread was unreal.  I would definitely ask next time I'm there if I can just buy an order of that bread.  They intend for you to make a little sandwich and I loved that originality.  We then got the stuffed cabbage dish and added the duck egg (duh).  The mushroom sauce was outstanding as was the polenta.  Our only complaint was that the egg was slightly over so some of the yolk had solidified but I know 10 seconds will do this.  I'm going to save the best for last but the ragu was literally amazing.  I tried the sausage and thought 'wow, this is so good.'  Then I tried the pork, which just fell off the bone and was the perfect tender texture.  The pasta and sauce itself was splendid but then I tried the meatball and, at first, thought okay, this is all right.  About 8 seconds later I realized I had underestimated it and just started pointing at it as if instructing my friends to try it.  Best...meatball...ever.  Because we had a red sauce, we wanted a white or lighter sauce so we tried the pesto.  There is no protein in this dish but to say you won't miss it is a understatement.  This was hands down the best pesto any of us had ever had.  We asked if the server knew what kind of olive oil she uses but he wasn't sure.  It's likely not anything I could get my hands on but worth a try.  The basil and pine nuts were literally perfect as well.  I am going to dream about this pesto for the rest of my life.  If you don't try it, you will regret it.  This is a spot you need to try and some of the best Italian food I've ever eaten, inclusive of Italy.

Monteverde is the ideal restaurant for pasta lovers such as myself. Save yourself the effort of reading this review and just make a reservation already!

Monteverde is located in the West Loop which is a cool low key neighborhood without all the riff raff found in the tourist hot spots. The interior is rustic chique and service is constantly moving to keep cups filled and plates cleaned. The servers are quite informative and great at describing the dishes for you.

After some delicious wine and cocktails we ordered a scallop appetizer to tease the palate. My entree was the wok seared arrabiata which blew me away with great spice and complex savory and herbal notes. The portion was perfect for my liking however it would be small for big eaters. My wife ordered the cacio whey pepe which was creamy with the right amount of parmesan and pepper to make it a dish worth craving everyday. For dessert I ordered a mango sorbet which was smooth and fruity without the weird icey texture that plagues many other sorbets. A cookie was thrown in that I can only describe as a texture between a biscuit and a marshmallow with a flavor of coconut and chocolate.

It goes without saying that the pasta was perfectly prepared in it dishes. They have a single chef dedicated to making pasta to order and he/she is stationed immediately behind the bar so you can watch the prep.

Overall I think this dinner was an absolute riot!  I'll come back here for sure.

closing out april with a bang by reviewing one of my favorite dining experiences over the past few months.

we came with a group of 6 people and basically ordered most of the highlights off the menu to ensure we'd get to try a mix of different dishes.

don't want to bore you by going into all the details for every dish we tried, but suffice to say that you really can't go wrong with chef sarah grueneberg at the helm.

the food here is not only hearty and reminds me of delicious pasta meals that i've had in italy, but also just smells and looks amazing with plenty of fresh ingredients. i've always stood by the fact that you eat with your eyes and nose as much as your mouth and stomach. and monteverde really knows how to appeal to all the senses.

the semi-open kitchen concept is also something i've always appreciated, so i can watch chefs work while i eat. there's something really cool and satisfying about watching a well-run kitchen work their magic.

best of all, prices are reasonable which makes this restaurant more accessible for a delicious dining out experience. and won't break the bank if you want to come back over and over again.

review.des:
We wanted to check out Monteverde now for about 9 months, my fiancé and I finally settled for a 5:15 reservation on a Tuesday night.  It impossible to get a reservation! The place is really cute and actually not as big as I would have expected.

I'll be completely honest- I'm not sure if I hyped up this place too much for myself or what but I was pretty disappointed with the food.  To start, my fiancé ordered himself an octopus appetizer which he really enjoyed but he thought the onion(?) that came on the stick overpowered the octopus which was otherwise delicious.  

For the rest of the meal, we decided to split 3 pastas, since this is an Italian restaurant after all.  We started with the tortellini which came in a broth.  It was different and very soup like but I enjoyed it.  The next pasta was a daily special with pancetta and parpadelli.  I really wished there was more meat in the pasta.  The sauce had a spice to it from the chili flakes, but in general the dish was just okay.  To finish we had the cacio whey pepe.  It was what I expected taste-wise: peppery and cheesy.  However I was greatly disappointed that our pasta was underdone- no, I don't mean al dente.  There were a couple pieces that were difficult to bite and hurt my teeth.  This was particularly disappointing because this means the pasta was probably not fresh, but I had higher exceptions of such a highly regarded Italian restaurant.  My fiancé did not enjoy any of the pasta dishes we tried.

To finish the dinner, we had the star of the dinner-the dessert.  A beautiful and delicious chocolate tart which we paired with a couple of boozy espressos.

The service was wonderful and attentive.

Overall, I'm not sure I will be back.  I did not think the pastas were memorable and the portions fairly small.  Walking out, there was a table that got one of the large entree dishes and that actually looked good, so I might consider coming back to try that if they accept walk ins at the bar but I do not see myself going out of the way to come back any time soon.

AMAZING! I am not a fan of going out for Italian food because I figure it's just pasta. But this placed blew me out of the water. We came here for brunch on a Sunday at 1:45. We started off with the zeppoles, 2 octopus sticks, poached eggs in sauce, 2 meatballs, and arancini. The hubby and I were sooo full. The Bloody Mary was delicious and I had the Bob Ross which didn't even taste alcoholic! Our waitress was super sweet, informative and amazing. We even got a piece of birthday cake with a candle for my 21st birthday (for the 9th time).

DEFINITELY GO HERE!

Amazing!!! Everything about this place is amazing. Loved the atmphosere, the service, the wine, and of course the food!

I had called about 2 weeks ahead for a reservation but was told they were completely booked. They told me bar seating and patio seating were first come first served though. We got there right when they opened at 5 and they were able to seat us at a table.

Our server was fantastic. He was helpful and very attentive.

We each got a glass of the sangiovese which was great! The breadsticks they give you at the table were great too! Being our first time here we wanted to try everything! Our server recommended ordering several plates as he said the menu is designed around family style dining.  We ended up getting one of the specialty pastas with fresh truffles on it-- it was by far my favorite thing of the night! I am still craving it! Truffles are the best thing ever! We also got the arrabiata which was spicy and delicious. The shrimp is chopped into bite sized pieces. These were or first two courses and we were definitely already full. But we had ordered a small order of the redfish too. The small portion was the perfect size. It was so flavorful!

Since we were celebrating a birthday they brought out a piece of funfetti ice cream cake which was super cute! The dessert menu looked great though! Im dying to try their straciatella gelato-- it's my favorite flavor!!

We will definitely be back! Thank you Monteverde for a great night!

Food:
+ tomato cucumber salad - very good, large portion, fresh, loved everything except for the small fennel pieces on top

+ ahi tuna crudo - liked eating it with the sesame cracker, tuna was a little fishy, but the watermelon paired well with the tuna overall

+ hand cut pappardelle - loved the noodles and everything about this dish, none of the ingredients overpowered another, very flavorful

+ wok-fried arrabbiata - usually gravitate towards pasta like this with garlic, tomato-based sauce, and shrimp, wished it was more spicy, dish was good but started to taste very shrimp-y as we kept eating it

Service:
+ professional, courteous
+ a little slow at times

Ambience:
+ romantic, dimly lit, very busy
+ perfect for dates, small group gatherings
+ there was a date going on right next to us and my friend and I both felt a bit awkward at times with all the intimacy and hand holding (but can't blame the restaurant for that)
+ seemed like more of an older crowd than other places

pics.caption: Tomato cucumber salad + ahi tuna crudo

review.des:
My boyfriend and I went here for one of my last big meals in the city. I had been trying to get weekend reservations here for forever. I ended up just making one for brunch time. WORTH IT. So the pasta was amazing. We had the cacio e pepe and the gnocchi type pasta in pesto. Now cacio e pepe is one of my favorite foods, but that pesto. Oh my god, it was good. Just a little citrusy, which added a brightness that was really nice amongst all the richness of the other pasta. We also had the burrata appetizer. DO NOT PASS THIS UP. The tiny rolls that came with were to die for. The cocktail I had was delicious, the boyfriend is non-alcoholic, so he didn't appreciate it, but it was great.

We were lucky enough to have the chef come ask us how our food was, which was a great touch. I will be back as soon as I get back to my city. 'Til then, I'll be in STL dreaming of my chicago home and pasta.

pics.caption: Smoked fish dip. I thought I wouldn't like the grainy crackers. Boy, was I wrong.
The burratta. That bread with rosemary was to die for.

review.des:
Great place to sit at the bar and enjoy some delicious wine and Italian food. All their pastas are freshly made!

The octopus was THE BEST octopus I've ever had. It is so tender! The sauce it comes with is also a great touch.

The "textbook" wine was my favorite! Such a good California cab.

The wok fried arrabiata was a great semi spicy pasta dish! Had white and black taglioni with ground gulf shrimp and garlic hot pepper oil. Wasn't too heavy of a pasta dish.

Got a side of the soppresseta meatball, which was great too! Just an overall lovely experience.

pics.caption: Wok fried arrabiata. Get this if you like a little spice!

review.des: Service was outstanding. I really loved the inside especially the pasta prep in the center. We went on a Saturday for an early dinner with another couple. We shared plates so we had the opportunity to try a lot. The little gnocci pesto was AMAZING. No joke one of the best pasta dishes I've ever had and I've been to Italy. I would give it a 4 because I wasn't crazy about the large ragu dish but everyone else enjoyed it so does not seem fair to doc stars for that.

pics.caption: Very cool presentation. They tell you to mix it up. Tad bit spicy!!

review.des:
Monteverde has stand-out Italian food in a down-to-earth setting. And I'm definitely a fan!

I came here for my birthday, and it was a darn good pick. The cacio whey pepe dish just might have been the best pasta I've ever had. Ever. It was such a far cry from the classic cacio e pepe that can often be made just as well at home. And in all my years with celiac disease, I've never seen gluten free pasta shaped in large tubes, and I've never had gluten free pasta that tasted quite so good either! My only wish is that there had been just a liiittle bit more. My fiancé's arrabbiata pasta looked like a much larger portion, and he kept commenting about feeling guilty still eating when I'd already finished!  

We weren't huge fans of the drinks (I had a glass of the pinot negro and he had the "birch please" cocktail), but the pasta was a hit all around. We overheard a waiter mention to a table next to us that dishes are meant to be shared, so next time, we'll order an appetizer too or three pastas to share.

Also, a word to the wise: definitely make a reservation in advance! I tried to do so a couple of nights before, thinking it wouldn't be bad for a weeknight and just two people, but the only opening was 10pm! We waited an hour for a table without a reservation, but I can imagine this place gets insane on the weekend.

A serious score here. Everything on the menu was A++ but my favorite standout was the Ragu. I woke up the next morning thinking about it. The meatballs and sausage were so damn good...heck, the veal too...the whole plate of Ragu blew my mind.
Not to take away from the rest of the menu which we sampled extensively, it was all some of the best Italian food to be offered!

Special shout out to the bartender, super cool dude. His Irish impression is spot on!

I was SOOO excited for Monteverde. After an unsuccessful (and anxiety-inducing) attempt at getting seated at the bar area, my friend and I finally came with a reservation excited to dine in a civilized way. (The bar area seating is not monitored and coordinated by the restaurant. You watch current guests like a hawk and snatch a spot when one opens up, often competing with other people waiting.) Honestly our experience was disappointing. Definitely a 3.5, tops, in my book. There were some delicious bites but the flavors got very much the same and underwhelming the more we ate.

We got the following:
:: skate schnitzel :: Very different from traditional schnitzel due to the use of fish, chili, and green onions. Yummy, unexpected, but a bit salty overall.
:: gnocchetti con pesto :: Our server mentioned the chef instructed no mixing so that we could taste different flavors in each bite. We obliged. And yet, I feel the flavors were flat. The cheese was very nice, so was the pesto. But I think it was missing something more than two pieces of basils to cut through the richness.
:: wok-fried shrimp arrabiata :: Pasta was al dente and the flavors were good. But I was hoping for more of a kick.
:: ice cream and sorbet w/ forgotten cookies :: Pleasantly surprised by the portion for only $7. For Ice-cream, the coconut milk and walnut crunch flavors were delicious. Also loved the passion fruit sorbet.

Bottom line - Personally for me it was a worthy visit, but not worthy enough for me to want to come back to try the ragu or more seasonal stuff like summer truffle pasta. I feel it's a place for celebratory occasions and best if you have a bigger party (at least 4) so you can have a little bit of everything.

Stopped in without a reso Friday night around 6:45 and was quoted a an hr wait, which isn't bad at all for the size of the place. They have cute outdoor space that runs along the front and side of the restaurant. Table was ready after only 30 mins, woohoo! My friend and I split a bottle of Nero d'Avalo, got the stuffed cabbage for an app, and shared the gnocchetti with pesto and cacio y pepe. Yum yum yum! The stuffed cabbage is a MUST! Pastas were great too, very saucy and seasoned.

Second time was as great as I remember the first being. Will definitely be back, ideally on the patio next time!

Went here with the besties for a night out and absolutely loved it! The waiter provided great suggestions for food and wine! Had an amazing dish of pasta with lamb and be sure to save room for dessert!

Monteverde is easily my favorite Italian restaurant in the city of Chicago. Chef Sarah is an extremely talented and accomplished chef (having spent a considerable amount of time running the kitchen at the Michelin rated, Spiaggia prior to this endeavor).

She brings her outstanding culinary techniques to Monteverde, and evidence of this is displayed dish after dish after dish.

We ordered the lamb ravioli as well as the Ragu Alla Napoletana.

The lamb ravioli blew my mind, however the RAN made me squirm in my seat. First, the dish is huge. Please split this with two people. Second, every single component of the dish was prepared spectacularly and tasted way too good. There is just something about fresh, housemade pasta. that cannot be beat.

The best part about Monteverde, is that Chef Sarah tweaks different ingredient pairings, however, she stays within a relative realm of traditional pairings so it doesn't at all come across like she's trying too hard to be "unique" or "one of a kind."

What you get at Monteverde is traditional cuisine, impeccably prepared.

So glad we decided to come here. One person in our party arrived early and secured a table for all four. We knew the wait would be a bit, without a reservation.

We wanted to share plates here and try a bit of everything. So, we ordered lots of pasta! Monteverde is well known for their handmade pastas and you can see it resting inside before being cooked to perfection.

So, we ordered the Cacio Whey Pepe (Mancini bucatini, pecorino Romano, ricotta whey, four peppercorn blend) This is a traditional pasta, cheese and pepper dish. Simple but fantastic!

Next we ordered the Gnocchetti con Pesto (housemade ricotta, basil, Tuscan pinenuts, Sardinian pecorino). It's very pesto-y but it was creamy too. A very good choice.

Finally we ordered the Ragu alla Napoletanna (fusilli rustico, cacciatore sausage, soppressata meatball, tomato braised pork shank, wild oregano). This was a mound of a dish, fit for a table of 4 to enjoy. There were lots of flavors from the pasta to the meatballs to the sausages - it was all fantastic!

My only wish was that they offered a tiramisu for dessert, but I can see why Monteverde is a local favorite and deserves every star on the chart. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit!
